english: The Migration Service of Turkmenistan must provide administrative act to Nurgeldy Halykov by January 3. The agency has 30 days (i.e., until January 3) for voluntary fulfillment of the court's decision. This is the maximum time set for such cases. If the migration service refuses to fulfill this obligation, then the court begins compulsory enforcement.

The Turkmen Ministry of Internal Affairs found no grounds for early release of Mansur Mingelov. The human rights activist suffers from severe osteopathic tuberculosis and according to the law should be released. This was acknowledged by both authorities and the law. In September, Mingelov's family appealed to the General Prosecutors Office and the Ministry of Internal Affairs with a request to start his early release process. On October 20th, they received an overall answer from the Department for Execution of Punishments in the Ministry of Internal Affairs - refusal. According to the letter, officials 'studied all evidence' and concluded that it 'does not correspond to the requirements of the current legal framework of Turkmenistan.' There is a sick person serving a long-term illegal sentence; there is a law clearly stating that such people should be released. Only political will from President Serdar Berdymukhamedov's country is missing for Mingelov (and other political prisoners) release. The early release would strengthen the image of Turkmenistan and its leader on the international arena.

The Ukrainian embassy in Turkmenistan, with the help of France and the USA, handed over two cars to the 21st Mechanized Brigade of the Armed Forces of Ukraine. The Volkswagen minivan and Toyota SUV (still bearing Turkmen license plates) were acquired by the French and US embassies in Turkmenistan, as well as Ukrainian businessmen. These vehicles will be used by mobile combat groups.

english: Company Buried Hill has filed a lawsuit against Turkmenistan in an international arbitration. In 2007, Buried Hill received a license to explore the disputed oil field 'Serdar', but did not conduct any drilling due to Azerbaijan's (neighbours called it 'Kypaz') strong stance. At the beginning of 2021, Turkmenistan and Azerbaijan agreed to jointly develop and exploit hydrocarbon resources from this field, which was renamed 'Dostluk'. According to our sources, Buried Hill hoped to join the exploration and drilling project but apparently was not included. Who will represent both sides in court?

In the area of Shohmansur, in the Hovaron mahalle (Eastern Hills), there have been a series of car thefts. The police conducted several operational and investigative measures and arrested residents of the capital Rahmaddin Davlatov, Umed Shamsov, and Saidakram Zarzod as suspects. During preliminary investigation it was established that 'within several days, the detained smashed more than 24 cars' windows, stole personal items, including money and phones, causing various material damage to victims.' 'Currently, the detained are in custody, the preliminary investigation continues,' - informs the city police department. The police also recommends citizens who were affected by this group of actions to contact the police at (+992) 018020202. More news Telegram

Russia proposes to ban international incoming calls without the caller's consent. The government plans to introduce a ban on such calls, which will be marked. This proposal is part of measures to protect citizens from phone and internet fraud, according to TASS. In total, about 20 initiatives are included in this package. Among other things, it proposes limiting the number of bank cards that a person can have, introducing children's SIM cards with parental control over unwanted content.

In China, three women were detained for trying to transport live bamboo worms on their person. Customs officers found the first woman with a kilogram of live worms in her pants. They searched the lady and discovered more live bamboo worms in her pants pockets. But the search continued, as two other Chinese women had also been caught with live worms in their underwear and backpacks. Bamboo worms are a local delicacy that can be sold for substantial money at markets, but importing live insects without permits and sanitary inspections is prohibited.

The team "Sardor" from the city of Tursunzoda won against the team "Hulbuk" district in transition matches, becoming the first time in its history to enter the highest league of Tajikistan football. Sardor finished second in the First League last season and according to regulations, played two transition matches with the team that finished last this year, which was Hulbuk. The first match ended in a draw (2:2), and the second one - 2:0 in favor of Sardor. After this defeat, Hulbuk left the highest league and entered the First League. Sardor from Tursunzoda, founded in 2022, will now for the first time enter the highest league of Tajikistan.

Orda.kz, , , . 

 Facebook.

 , , . 

 ORDA.kz . . , .

 . Freedom Finance, . .

english: Minister of Culture and Information of Kazakhstan Aida Balayeva reacted to criminal cases against the leadership of information agencies KazTAG and Orda.kz, stating that state organs can only defend media rights if their own editorial boards comply with the law. She posted this on her page in Facebook. According to Balayeva, moving disputes between subjects into a legal framework means any involvement by the ministry could be seen as pressure on judicial bodies. The beginning of the investigation against main editor of Orda.kz Gulnara Bazkenova was announced at the beginning of December, she is suspected of 'repeatedly and intentionally spreading false information.' The court ordered her to stay in home arrest for two months while ongoing investigative actions. Recently it became known about the initiation of a criminal case against KazTAG's CEO Aset Matayev and main editor Amir Kasenov. The basis was a statement by Freedom Finance, whose leaders saw publications in the agency as allegedly fraudulent schemes. Both journalists were declared suspects.

english: Scammers spread fake information from RC Cola Tajikistan. In the Tajik social media segment, there is a scam spreading about cash prizes from the company on its anniversary. Scammers send fake messages from RC Cola Tajikistan asking to complete an online survey after which they promise monetary rewards. Be careful! This information does not correspond to reality and has nothing to do with the company. Company 'Obi Zool' asks not to trust these publications, not to click on suspicious links, and not to provide personal data and credentials. All official information is published only on the RC Cola Tajikistan and Obi Zool company pages.

Russian Olympic mascot 'Mishka' from the 1980 Moscow Olympics will be Russia's olympic team mascot for the 2026 Games in Italy. The new mascot is being registered as a trademark by the Russian Sports Ministry and the Olympic Committee.

Fruz Negmatzade is not just a gallery owner and the owner of two art spaces, but also a person who has transformed his family's creative legacy into a recognizable Tajik brand. Inspiration and starting point for his business were paintings by his father - famous artist Farrokh Negmatzade. Today it's not only paintings and their reproductions, but ceramics, embroidery, mosaic, jewelry and much more. All based on or inspired by the works of the Honored Artist of Tajikistan Farrokh Negmatzade.

In Tajikistan, criminal penalties have been introduced for the production of cryptocurrencies using 'stolen electricity'. The Prosecutor General stated that numerous cases of electricity theft were found to be used by mining farms, which in some areas artificially created a shortage and led to limits on electricity. As a result, Tajikistan introduces criminal penalties for illegal use of electricity for producing virtual assets or cryptocurrencies. Penalties include fines from 15 to 75 thousand somoni and up to 8 years imprisonment.

Nomination 'Culinary Culture of Sumanak' included in the Representative List of the Intangible Cultural Heritage of UNESCO. Today, on December 10, at the 20th session of the Joint Government Committee for Intangible Cultural Heritage of UNESCO in New Delhi, a national nomination from the Republic of Tajikistan 'Culinary Culture of Sumanak' was accepted and included in the Representative List of the Intangible Cultural Heritage of UNESCO. The culinary culture of Sumanak is a collective ritual lasting many hours related to celebrating Navruz, symbolizing unity, patience, and the arrival of spring. The process includes germinating wheat, grinding it, and long cooking (20-24 hours). Women take turns stirring the dish in a large cauldron, accompanied by singing, dancing, making wishes, and patterns on the finished dish interpreting as omens. A stone or nut is placed at the bottom of the cauldron to prevent burning, and if you eat something with a stone, it means your wish will come true.

What to do for pensioners who can't come to the office for re-registration? #asked, answered. Elderly pensioners and those with disabilities due to health reasons that cannot come to the office will have their registration done at home by agency staff. Also, in the Agency of Pensions and Social Protection, they were informed that all pensioners must go through a relocation based on their place of residence. For this, you need to visit local offices with identification documents. During the re-registration period, offices work without weekends from 8 AM to 9 PM, and the procedure is free. Do you have any questions? - write us in direct messages.

A man from Ghana named Ebosus Jesus is gaining popularity on social media after videos showing him building eight wooden boats. He claims he will finish them by December 25, 2025 - the date when, according to him, a worldwide flood will begin and he wants to save humanity. He says he received a divine vision warning of three-year rain starting on that day. His plan is to live on the boat for the entire period. Meanwhile, skeptics point out technical problems: lack of engines, rudder, and sufficient strength of the hull. Commentators note that even in a major flood, such boats would likely not last long on water or be controllable.
Reminder about penalties for importing firecrackers in Tajikistan. There are also fines for using fireworks by your children!

The school of young content makers 'Asia-Plus' has ended. Eight intense weeks and 14 beginners in journalism and content creation have made a powerful leap forward. Participants learned to create quality content, verify facts, work with AI, promote materials on social media, and edit their projects. The most active received certificates and commemorative gifts. At the final ceremony, participants presented their own projects - some of which are already published on 'Asia-Plus' website. The Ambassador of EU in Tajikistan Radoslav Darasky attended the event and noted that the efforts of young specialists impress him, and the development of their skills is an important contribution to creating strong and responsible media content.

Highlights from the evening news on December 10th in Tajikistan: vaccination progress against HPV, uranium legacy cleanup costs, pensioner registration issues, student death investigation, fake RC Cola messages, low daily AI usage rate, artist son's business success, journalist award, cultural heritage inclusion, and three judoists receiving international certifications.

subject: prices, inflation
english: In Tajikistan, liquefied gas has fallen in price after two weeks of rising prices. The antimonopoly service explained the reason.

Tajik chess players are participating in the President Cup of Uzbekistan. In Tashkent, an international tournament is taking place with over 200 participants, including FIDE masters from various countries, including Tajikistan. Ali Sher Karimov (2290), the current country champion, has scored 4 out of 6 and holds a position in the upper part of the table. In group 'B', players are: Saidaakhror Kurbonov (1844) - 4/6, Nagmat Ziyaev (1814) - 4/6, Ahmad Saidakramzoda (1502) - 3/6. More news Telegram

China demanded that the Taliban investigate the killing of its citizens in Tajikistan, carried out from Afghan territory. UN representative Fu Kun urged the government of the Taliban to conduct a 'serious investigation' into the death of Chinese citizens in Tajikistan as a result of attacks carried out from Afghan territory.

The Constitutional Court of Kyrgyzstan blocked the idea of reinstating capital punishment. The court ruled that such a measure is unconstitutional and violates international obligations. President Sadyr Japarov requested to reintroduce capital punishment for raping children and murder, committed with rape. The court emphasized human rights as the highest value in the Constitution and protection of life and prohibition of capital punishment are fundamental principles. It also noted Kyrgyzstan's international commitments: norms of international law are part of the legal system.

The team 'Sipar' from Hudjand won the Tajikistan Cup football five championship, defeating in the final the Dushanbe team 'So-ro company'. The final match between the two teams took place on December 10th in Dushanbe and ended with a score of 3:2 in favor of the coach's students Sergei Koridze from Ukraine, who leads 'Sipar'. Thanks to this victory, 'Sipar' won the Cup of Tajikistan and received 10 thousand somoni prize money. The second place team 'So-ro company' was awarded with 5 thousand somoni.

Supporters of the 'Hojjat' football club have sent a program for its development to the chairman of Sogd Region Radjab Ahmadzoda. The fans prepared a detailed analysis of the season-2025 results and submitted it. They outlined key problems with the team and proposed reforms in management and player training. The reason was approaching the 50th anniversary of the club, which supporters want to turn into an update point.

A photo of a gorilla baby dancing became the funniest in 2025. Wildlife Comedy Awards jury announced winners - about 10,000 works from 108 countries were submitted. The main prize went to Mark Meta Cohen's British photographer for his 'Give Five' shot taken during an expedition in Virunga mountains in Rwanda. The baby gorilla performed acrobatics and jumped high with its legs.

subject: trade, exports, imports, investment, fdi
english: Ministry of Economic Development and Trade of Tajikistan and Korea International Cooperation Agency (KOICA) signed a protocol of negotiations on the implementation of a grant project worth $6.5 million to develop digitalization of state functions. The document was signed within declared 2025-2030 years 'Years of development of digital economy and innovations', as well as in order to implement activities 'Medium-term program for the development of digital economy on 2021-2025 years'. Within the project, it is planned to create a unified platform for monitoring and evaluating strategic documents, as well as digitization of coordination and distribution processes of applicants in higher, secondary and vocational education institutions. Director of KOICA Kang Sung-hun noted that the agency will provide all necessary resources for successful implementation of industry projects.

How to pay for parking? You can choose one of the following ways:
- Via QR code;
- Via mobile wallet
- Via website
For more details on how to pay - in our video.

subject: debt, exports, imports, investment, FDI, budget, deficit, trade, employment, wages, industrial production, reserves, current account, debt, GDP, inflation, interest rates, exchange rate
english: The country is planning to make all payments for certain goods and services exclusively through bank cards or electronic payment systems starting in 2026. The rules will gradually take effect from April 1st. All state services, utilities (electricity, natural gas, water), alcohol and tobacco products, fuel at gas stations, electricity on charging stations, purchases of any real estate, purchases of vehicles categories M, N, O and G (i.e., passenger cars, buses, trucks, etc.), and all goods and services over 25 million sum ($2100) will be paid exclusively through bank cards or electronic payment systems. By January 1st, 2026, all commercial and service enterprises must implement unified payment QR codes. From January 1st, 2026, foreign companies selling electronic services and goods to Uzbekistan citizens will face strict requirements for registration. If the company does not register within 30 days after notification, its activities in the country will be restricted. The authorities plan to reduce the shadow sector share of GDP by 1.3 times by 2030. It is expected that by this time, the share of non-cash payments in trade and service sectors will reach 75%. More news Telegram

Residents of the country have been complaining about stricter restrictions on electricity supply for the last month. Energy suppliers blame a decrease in water levels at Nurek Hydroelectric Power Station (NHS). The cause of low water levels was attributed to insufficient rainfall. Now, energy officials say that after recent rainfalls, the inflow of water into the NHS has increased, which has improved electricity supply and residents receive power for 4-5 hours a day. Residents themselves state they get no more than 1-3 hours of electricity per day.

A court in Russia has issued its first fine for searching 'extremist' content. A 20-year-old resident of Kamensk-Uralsky city, Sergey Glukhikh, was fined 3,000 rubles under a new administrative article about searching materials that the Russian authorities consider 'extremist'. The fine was issued for Glukhikh's search of materials related to the Russian Volunteer Corps and Battalion 'A', which are declared 'terrorist organizations' in Russia. His defense argued that Glukhikh did not specifically seek information but simply 'came across symbols, materials banned organizations' while surfing the internet. It remains unclear how authorities learned what pages Glukhikh was viewing. The law prohibiting searching for 'extremist materials' was signed by Russian President Vladimir Putin on July 31 and came into effect from September 1. This provision carries a fine of up to five thousand rubles.

The territory of the Botashad 'Iram Gods' in Dushanbe turned into a festive space for one day, where everyone could feel the atmosphere of European Christmas. Visitors were greeted by colorful kiosks, German desserts and baked goods. Throughout the park, festive melodies played, there were delicious aromas, and bright lights created the feeling of a real winter fairy tale - as if part of Germany's embassy had moved to Dushanbe for one day.

Former football player of Real Madrid and Barcelona, Robert Prosineki, has been appointed as the head coach of Kyrgyzstan's national team. The contract between 56-year-old Prosineki and Kamchybek Tashiev, president of the Football Federation of Kyrgyz Republic, was signed on December 10th. Prosineki will work in the role of head coach for one year and a month. If the national team performs well at the 2027 Asian Cup, the contract will be extended for three more years. Robert Prosineki is a former national player of Croatia. He previously played for clubs like Real Madrid, Barcelona (both Spain), Dinamo Zagreb (Croatia) and Red Star Belgrade (Serbia). He has also worked as head coach for national teams of Azerbaijan, Bosnia and Herzegovina, and clubs like Red Star Belgrade and Olympiacos. For several years he was also part of the coaching staff of Croatia's national team.

Citizens of Russia in 2025: only 4 Tajiks. According to RIA Novosti, a non-released document, 71 people received Russian citizenship this year (including six children). The most frequent recipients were French citizens (32 adults and four children), followed by Americans and Germans (six and five respectively). Among the four Tajik citizens who obtained Russian passports - two children. Other holders of Russian passports: four from Italy, three Ukrainians, three Russians born, two Serbs, and two from Lebanon. In 2025, a Russian passport was also acquired by people born in Morocco, Bosnia and Herzegovina, Turkey, Kazakhstan, Syria, Iran, Cameroon, the UK, Croatia, and Yugoslavia (one person each). For comparison, in 2022 (latest available statistics of the Ministry of Internal Affairs of Russia on citizenship acquisition by countries) Russian citizenship was acquired by over 173 thousand Tajiks. In 2024, a total of 209 thousand people became new citizens of Russia from various countries, including Tajikistan (no specific numbers are provided).

In Dushanbe tonight, movement will be restricted on several streets. According to the city's Ministry of Internal Affairs, from 6 PM to 8 PM today (11 December), all types of transport will be blocked on Rudaki Prospect and also on Sadulariyev Street, Alisher Donish Street, and Mamat Mastongulov Street. Drivers are asked to use adjacent streets and not park in unauthorized places.

The restaurant 'Ko'hi Parfenaon' invites you to unforgettable new year corporate events! You will enjoy a vibrant show program, tasty menu and atmosphere of magic:
Jazz group 'Borba'd' - live music and cozy evening
Firuz Pal'alev - heartfelt songs
Bahter Ibrokhimov - lively retro hits
Mino - bright and danceable songs
DJ J-Dee - modern rhythms and energy
Santa Claus and Snowgirrl - bring joy and festive mood
Free dates for new year corporate events:
21, 22, 23, 24, 29 December!
Contact details: +7 (83) 050-005
Don't miss the best evening for your company!

Helping to clear debris after catastrophic floods in Indonesia are elephants. Trained animals move heavy objects, including fallen trees that block roads, reports the country's Agency for Natural Resources Protection. The number of deaths from flooding and landslides on Sumatra island has risen to 960 people. More than 5,000 have been injured, with 274 still missing. Across five countries in the region Indonesia, Sri Lanka, Malaysia, Thailand, and Vietnam a series of tropical storms and monsoon rains at the end of November resulted in over 1,800 deaths. The cost of recovery on Sumatra alone could reach $3.1 billion.

In Uzbekistan, plans are underway to start producing humanoid robots. As a result of the Uzbek-Korean business dialogue, a memorandum of understanding was signed between the 'Uzeltexsanat' union and one of South Korea's leading companies in robotics, Robotis. The document includes creating production facilities for humanoid robots, establishing a technological base, and manufacturing capacity. Tashkent plans to allocate a 66,000 square meter production site for this purpose. Additionally, the document outlines the creation of a system for training specialists in the new industry. Robotis was founded in Seoul in 1999 and specializes in modular robotic systems and autonomous service robots.
Transfermarkt updated the list of Asia and Oceania's most expensive football leagues, considering the total player cost, number of foreign players, age balance, and depth of squad. More details.

The opera and ballet theater named after C. Ayni invites for a children's New Year performance 'Ded Moroz's Magic Christmas Tree'. The show will be held on December 21st and 28th, featuring stories like 'Old Man ', 'Aladdin and the Genie', and many other beloved characters that will help lost toys reach Ded Moroz to save New Year. Children and their parents can enjoy colorful songs, dances, vivid decorations, and costumes. Time: 12:00. Ticket price: 30 somoni. Tickets are available at the theater (2216291) or on Echipta.tj website.

A private production company in Uzbekistan is working on a joint Tajik-Uzbek film about Abdurakhmon Jamo and Ali Sher Nava'i titled 'The Glitter of Stars: Jamo and Nava'i'. This was reported by the Tajik director of the film, Fayzullo Fayzov. The shooting process has not yet been completed. Some scenes are to be shot in the studio of Uzbekfilm, including scenes with Shah Bahodin. There is still one week of filming left, but the throne of Shah Bahodin has not yet been prepared. To avoid wasting time, we have already spent almost 20 days editing the film. It is expected that the film about Jamo and Nava'i will be presented to viewers in the run-up to the celebration of Navruz in 2026.

US Department of Homeland Security reported that since Donald Trump took office, 2.5 million illegal immigrants have left the country. The agency published a report stating that from January 2025, 605 thousand illegal migrants were forcibly expelled and another 1.9 million people voluntarily left the US territory. It also mentions prioritizing deporting the most dangerous offenders - those who committed serious crimes. Additionally, it urges immigrants to use a special app for free return home and receive $1000 in one-time assistance. Earlier, it was reported that since January, Trump administration revoked 85 thousand visas of all categories. Among them were over 8 thousand student visas. According to the State Department, about half of annulled visas last year were related to violations: driving under the influence, attacks and thefts. Reasons for the other half of visa revocations are not disclosed.

subject: inflation, interest rates, exchange rate, reserves, current account, budget, deficit, debt, investment, FDI
english: The Nobel Committee announced the winners of the prizes for 2025, recognizing scientists and public figures whose achievements have significantly influenced science, society, and global politics. The awards were presented on December 10 in Stockholm.

subject: inflation, industrial production, trade, exports, imports, investment, FDI
english: In Tajikistan, seasonal influenza strains A (H3N2) and H1N1 are circulating. These viruses have been common in the country for many years during annual flu seasons. However, doctors from some regions report a more pronounced increase in illnesses with symptoms not seen last season.

Police in the city district of Sino arrested a suspect accused of attempted rape. A 35-year-old man named Isfandiyar Pirnazarov used deceit to bring a woman to a hotel and tried to have sex with her by force, causing injuries. The victim resisted and jumped out of the window to escape, resulting in physical harm. The suspect is now in custody, and the investigation continues. Police also urge victims of Pirnazarov's actions to contact authorities at (+992) 018020202.

The financing of Tajikistan's priority projects, including the construction of Rogun Hydroelectric Power Station and social infrastructure, was discussed at a roundtable within the Financial Development Conference in Riyadh. Representatives from Islamic Development Bank, Qatar Fund for Arab Economic Development, Kuwait Fund for Arab Economic Development, Saudi Arabia Fund for Development, OPEC Fund for International Development, Abu Dhabi Fund for Development, and other international organizations participated in the meeting. The financial institutions expressed readiness to assist further financing of the project. Also, a separate meeting was held between Tajikistan's Finance Minister Fayziddin Qakhzhodzo and Regional Director of Abu Dhabi Fund for Development for Asia Abdul Almansouri. He stated that the fund is ready to continue participation in funding construction work at Rogun Hydroelectric Power Station. Parties agreed that further cooperation and participation of the Abu Dhabi Fund for Development in financing Tajikistan's priority objects will be discussed in separate meetings within the next few months.

In Dushanbe, a joint ecological laboratory between Tajikistan and China has been opened. In the Institute of Water Problems, Hydroenergy and Ecology at the Academy of Sciences of Tajikistan, a new joint lab with China is in operation for monitoring the environment and analyzing natural resources. The new lab allows scientists from both countries to conduct joint research, exchange data, and work on an international level using modern technologies. Equipment imported into Tajikistan for the first time includes a multi-parameter water quality analyzer, portable PM1000 air quality meter, and networked AQSN-822 air quality monitor.

The Tajik government is auctioning off the famous tea house 'Harbuz' again. The building, which has been unsold for over a year, will be sold on December 12th for more than $3 million. Built in the shape of a watermelon, it was opened ten years ago but authorities say it wasn't used effectively. In September last year, it was first put up for sale but no buyer emerged yet. The high price is reportedly the reason why nobody showed interest.

The government of Bulgaria has resigned. Prime Minister Rosen Gazinsky announced the resignation of the cabinet at an emergency press conference in parliament, according to BTA. The statement was made against the backdrop of plans for the parliament to vote on a no-confidence motion against the cabinet. BTA reports that mass anti-government protests have arisen in Bulgaria due to 'ambiguous budget plans' by the government, which later turned into dissatisfaction with the government over 'corruption, injustice and failures in many state sectors.' Protests in Bulgaria have been ongoing since late November, protesters were dissatisfied with the government's plans to raise social taxes for employers and dividend tax to increase spending on the state. Calls for the resignation of the government did not cease even after the cabinet 2 December revoked a controversial budget proposal for the next year.

An anonymous hacker group hacked the servers of company 'Mikord' - a key developer of the unified conscription registry in Russia. According to G. Sverdlin, head of the human rights project 'Idite Lesom', hackers contacted him and handed over large amounts of materials about the registry: technical and financial documentation, as well as source code. 'Thanks to the hack, the development of the Registry has been suspended at least for several months,' writes Sverdlin. Director of Mikord Ramil Gabdrahmanov confirmed the fact of hacking.

President Emomali Rahmon of Tajikistan flew today, December 11th, to Turkmenistan for participation in the International Forum of Peace and Trust. The head of state is accompanied by the minister of foreign affairs, the president's assistant on international relations, and other official representatives.

english: Time magazine named the creators of artificial intelligence as people of the year. The cover features leaders of major companies shaping the future of AI, compared to a famous photo from the Empire State Building.

China demanded that the Taliban investigate the deaths of its citizens in Tajikistan. Tajik officials said that rains have improved electricity supply, but residents of some regions say they get only 1-3 hours of light per day. Prices for coal, a main fuel for many families, have fallen after two weeks of growth in Tashkent. In Dushanbe, a group suspected of committing 11 serious crimes, including murder, has been arrested. The remains of a soldier from Tajikistan who died during World War II are being returned to his homeland after 84 years. How to pay for parking? A detailed instruction in the video. The building of the 'Habuzha' teahouse is again put up for sale. Auction - December 12. Fans of FC Khudzhanad have appealed to the head of Sogd with a program for the club's development.

english: The Kazakh national freight company's subsidiary takes a nearly $500 million loan to buy locomotives. The deal is guaranteed by Kaztemtrans and financed by Deutsche Bank Luxembourg, Banco Santander, and the U.S. Export-Import Bank. The operation exceeds half of the guarantor's asset value. Wabtec produces the equipment, which will be produced locally in Kazakhstan. The company has high debt levels and plans an IPO later this year.

"Cops on manners" detained friends in Afghanistan for costumes from the series 'Peaky Blinders'. In a province of Afghanistan, Herat, police stopped four young men due to their appearance. The young people dressed in the style of characters from the popular British series Peaky Blinders. The reason for investigation was a video in social media where boys walked on the street imitating gangsters at the beginning of the 20th century. The clips quickly gained popularity but caused dissatisfaction with the Ministry of Encouragement to Virtue and Prevention of Vice. The ministry considered such behavior spread 'foreign Western fashion'. "Such behavior is incompatible with Islamic values and Afghan culture", - quotes words from representatives of the ministry 'The Present Time'. Authorities did not officially arrest fans of the series. Instead, they strongly recommended them to stop such excursions and complete a special rehabilitation program.

The former head of KazPost became deputy director of the President's Administration. Asel Zhanasova got a new job in Acorde today, she took the post of Deputy Director of the President's Administration. Before this, the official was a counselor to Kassym-Jomart Tokayev - she only moved to this position in June of this year, leaving her post as Chairman of the Board of the AO 'KazPost'. In her career list also includes work as Vice Minister of Trade from 2020 to 2022. Zhanasova's achievements are noted by professional media: in 2025 she took the 18th place in the Forbes ranking of the most influential women in the country. Cuts and changes in political centers of Kazakhstan have been ongoing for several months. In late September, the president updated the composition of his advisors and assistants. In October, Deputy Director of the President's Administration left - he was previously responsible for internal politics. Now he works as a deputy akim of Almaty. Another notable figure is Zhansoz Imanaliyev, who was recently appointed head of the department of external policy.

A Uzbegian woman in Moscow was sentenced to 15 years in prison for allegedly financing a terrorist organization. The court found her guilty of supporting the international terrorist group 'Kataba Ta'hid wal-Jihad'. She provided bank details and access to mobile banking app, which allowed funds to be transferred to support militants fighting in Syria.

The Constitutional Court of Kyrgyzstan has officially rejected the idea of reinstating capital punishment. The judges reviewed a proposal to amend the main law that would allow executing criminals for rape and murder with sexual violence. The verdict is clear: this initiative contradicts the Constitution and international obligations of Kyrgyzstan. The court ruled that such issue cannot be put on referendum, and further discussions should be stopped. This means it's impossible to reintroduce shootings in Kyrgyzstan without violating the constitution.

english: The Ministry of Culture and Information in Kazakhstan refused to consider a petition against the ban on LGBT. The ministry officially rejected the collective appeal 'We are against laws banning LGBT people'. The petition appeared on Epetition platform on November 17, but did not pass moderation due to technical issues. In the Ministry of Culture and Information they said that authors violated the rules for filling in the form. They also cited that they do not have the power to review laws approved by parliament.
A passenger on a SCAT flight from Aktobe to Almaty died after an emergency landing. The pilot quickly landed the plane back in Aktobe, but medical help was ineffective.

Highlights from the Telegram channel 'Asia in Focus':
- Kazakhstan's Minister of Culture and Information, Vice Premier Aidar Baieva, refused to defend KazTAG and Orda.kz media outlets under pressure.
- A Kazakh MP demanded investigations into tariffs for Altel, Tele2, and Beeline due to cartel suspicions.
- Plans for another nuclear waste burial site in East Kazakhstan have been proposed.
- The Kazakh government is seeking the arrest of husband and mother-in-law of a murdered Kazakh former judge in Germany.
- A woman from Turkestan region found a newborn baby's body in a garbage bin.
- An OVD officer in Tashkent was arrested for taking a bribe to issue attractive license plates for a local resident.

In China, the former head of investment company China Huarong International was executed for 156 million USD bribes.

Uzbekistan's President Shavkat Mirziyoyev announced that in one year, they have collected 4 million tons of cotton.

A Tashkent resident was fined 82 million soms (about $300,000) for turning a vacant lot near the railway into a green zone and ordered to revert it back to a parking area.

english: Four people died in a traffic accident on the Almaty-Ust-Kamchensk road. The Kazakhstani railway company created a special commission to investigate after four workers died on rail tracks in Karaganda region. China publicly demanded that Taliwan investigate the deaths of its citizens after attacks at the Afghanistan-Tajikistan border. British Shell is ousting Russians from their share in KTK, Reuters reports citing sources. Kazakhstan lost 480 thousand tons of oil due to an attack on KTK. President of Iran visited Astana. Bishkek City Court upheld a decision against activist Rita Karasartova. In Dushanbe, organized group suspected of involvement in 11 serious crimes, including murder, was arrested. Papa John's pizza chain closes in Kazakhstan and Kyrgyzstan due to unprofitability. Wife accuses a university teacher of beatings.

Organ transplant racket in Tashkent, Uzbekistan. A group of 12 people who operated from 2023 to 2025 conducted 32 organ transplants. They used social media and those in need of organs for money. The defendants admitted guilt and apologized. All were sentenced under the law.

Could the conflict between China and Japan escalate into a military confrontation? Why have fighting resumed on the border of Thailand and Cambodia, and how are cities in Central Asia suffering from smog and what can be done to protect one's body?

In Almaty, over 50 people were poisoned by gas in a train. The incident occurred on the Almaty-2 railway station. All patients were urgently transported to city hospitals for full examination and medical care. Authorities reported that 10 children were hospitalized, including two in intensive care units.

In Uzbekistan, authorities intercepted a drug smuggling attempt from Kyrgyzstan. Police stopped a car in Andijan province carrying almost three kilograms of drugs. The driver and his accomplice were arrested for buying large quantities of hashish in Kyrgyzstan for $23,000 and planning to sell it on the black market in Tashkent.

The authorities of Uzbekistan promised to protect whistleblowers on corruption. In Uzbekistan, citizens who reported bribery are planning to be protected by special protective orders. This was announced during a presentation to the president on new measures against corruption. The authorities also want to implement a real mechanism for monetary incentives and establish a new badge 'For contributions in the fight against corruption'. Currently, the system is working poorly. In September, Director of the Agency Against Corruption Akmal Burhano said that by 2024, only 31 people were rewarded, with 28 receiving simple commendatory letters instead of the required payments from the budget. 'But there are several factors. The first problem is low citizen activity. The second is the persistent human factor: an automatic reward system has not yet been created.' explained the official.

The mayor of Sagynka, Shabikbaev, is being tried for bribery in the Hromtau district court. The city's head was arrested in November and charged with taking a bribe. The case has been completed quickly and materials have been sent to the court for substantive consideration. New elections will be held on January 11 next year.

Diplomats rescued citizens from Uzbekistan, Kazakhstan and Kyrgyzstan from slavery in Myanmar. Citizens were tricked into working in internet scams centers by fake job offers. After the operation ended on December 9th, all victims were returned to their home countries.

A 16-year-old girl fell from a zipline on the popular tourist trail Kammik in Uzbekistan. The incident occurred due to sudden technical issues with the attraction. Social media quickly spread video footage of the accident, showing the passenger struggling to hold onto the rope for some time before falling and landing on rocks. Authorities confirmed the fall and provided details about the rescue operation. The injured was promptly hospitalized in a medical center in Dan'gari district. Doctors have already conducted an examination and are now assessing the patient's condition as stable.

Highlights from the Telegram channel 'Asia in Focus':
- In Astana, a gas balloon explosion caused a tandoor to catch fire, resulting in burns for four people.
- A local resident of Kazakhstan was arrested for hacking accounts in Germany worth hundreds of thousands of euros.
- In Uzbekistan, natural gas shortages led to restrictions on methane refueling stations but no further details were provided.
- The remains of a Tajik soldier killed during World War II have been returned home after 84 years.
- A Uzbeks mother's son was sentenced to 15 years in prison and compulsory treatment for alcoholism.
- The head of the Zdorovye (Health) Department in Kostanay region, Kazakhstan, has been arrested on charges of abuse of power.
- Kyrgyz activist and videoblogger Aibek Tenizbay was detained under a case of 'incitement to racial, ethnic, national, religious or inter-regional hostility'.
- A 34-year-old man in Tashkent was sentenced to three years for participating in the war with Ukraine on Russia's side.
- Kazakhstan President Kassym-Jomart Tokayev invited Pope Francis to visit Kazakhstan.
- Import of chicken eggs has been banned in Kazakhstan for a month.

In Dushanbe, a group that committed a series of car thefts has been arrested. Over several days, they broke the windows of more than 24 vehicles belonging to citizens in the Havaron district of Shohmanskur. The suspects stole money and mobile phones, causing various material losses to victims. Citizens are advised to report any damage from this criminal group to the capital's police at (+992) 018020202.

Record rainfall and flooding in Iraq media. In the northeast of Iraq, in Sulaymaniyah province, there have been two days of extremely severe rainstorms. Heavy rains led to major floods. Preliminary data shows casualties among civilians.

Tajik chess players are successfully participating in the Uzbek Cup. The tournament is one of the strongest international chess competitions in the region, with over 200 athletes from different countries competing. Tajikistan's team is performing well and maintaining a strong position. Notable achievements include Ali Sher Karimov (2290 rating) who has scored 4 out of 6 points and Saiford Kurbonov (1844 rating), Negmat Ziyaev (1814 rating), and Ahmad Saidakramzoda (1502 rating). The press service wishes the athletes good luck and hopes for a successful conclusion to the tournament.

subject: trade, exports, imports, investment, FDI
english: In Dushanbe, a meeting of the Tajikistan Chemical Safety Commission was held. On December 9th, representatives from various ministries and agencies attended the meeting. The first and fourth items on the agenda were discussed by Deputy Chairman Shukurzoda Isfandiyar about approving the list of chemicals and chemical products allowed and prohibited in Tajikistan. The chairman of the Chemical Safety Commission Sulaymon Rizo also gave specific instructions for implementing a unified digital system for registering chemicals and chemical products, as well as other relevant issues.

The national nomination of Tajikistan 'Culinary Culture of Sumanak' has been included in the Representative List of the Intangible Cultural Heritage of Humanity by UNESCO. The decision was made on December 10th, 2023, at the 20th session of the Intergovernmental Committee for the Safeguarding of the Intangible Cultural Heritage of UNESCO in New Delhi. This nomination was prepared by the National Commission for UNESCO and submitted to the organization in 2023.

Tajik specialists in China discussed the implementation of modern water purification technologies. Tajik State Unitary Enterprise 'Dushanbevodokanal' specialists, on a business trip to the People's Republic of China, met with the General Director of the Water Resources Development Group of Province Shandong at the city of Shanxi. The purpose of the trip is to strengthen cooperation, learn from advanced experience and participate in the 'International Exhibition of Technologies and Equipment for Water Purification - China (Shanxi) 2025'. During the meeting, both sides discussed issues related to modernizing and reconstructing sewage treatment facilities, as well as improving the daily regulating basin system. The discussion covered technical and practical aspects of implementing modern solutions in water purification operations.
Tajikistan and Korea signed a grant agreement of $6.5 million for digitalizing government functions.

Tajikistan and China discussed future cooperation prospects. First Deputy Minister of Foreign Affairs of the Republic of Tajikistan Farroukh Hamrazodov met with Ambassador of the People's Republic of China to the Republic of Tajikistan Mr. Gu Zhizhun on December 10, 2025. The Ministry of Foreign Affairs of Tajikistan reported this. During the meeting, both sides discussed the current state of bilateral relations between Tajikistan and China as well as future cooperation in various fields. Topics included strengthening political dialogue, expanding economic and investment cooperation, and implementing joint projects in infrastructure and regional development. Both sides emphasized the importance of increasing contacts at all levels and their intention to coordinate actions for enhancing the effectiveness of bilateral cooperation. The meeting created favorable conditions for further deepening partnership relations between the Republic of Tajikistan and the People's Republic of China.

The International Festival 'Suzani Panjakent' will take place from December 12-13, 2025. The festival celebrates Penjikent's inclusion in the World Crafts Registry and includes a craft exhibition, exhibits by local and international masters, award ceremony, scientific-theoretical conference, press conference, and city tours. It is organized to promote national art, strengthen cultural ties, and exchange experiences between local and international artists and craftsmen.

The Huddo club 'Sipar' led by the Ukrainian coach Sergei Korzhuev won the Megafon Cup of Tajikistan-2025 football tournament. In the final match, which took place on December 10 in the sports complex of the Tax Committee of the Republic of Tajikistan in Dushanbe, 'Sipar' defeated the Dushanbe team 'Soro Company' with a score of 3:2. The goals were scored by Brazilian players Leonardo Correa Lemme, Felipe Vieira De Sa and Agnaldo Eduardo. The best player of the final match was recognized as Felipe Vieira De Sa from 'Sipar'. During the game, red cards were given to Rafael Kamilo (Sipar) for a handball on the 6th minute, Agnaldo Eduardo (Sipar) for two yellow cards and Fazil Sardorov (Soro Company) after the match for insulting the referee. The ceremony of awarding took place with Vice-President of the Football Federation of Tajikistan Iskandar Jalilov, Chairman of the Committee of Football of the FF Tadzhikistan Abduraimov Ismoilov, Executive Director of the company 'Megafon Tadzhikistan' Anatoly Izyumnikov and Director of the Football League of Tajikistan Bahtodor Mekhlov. The final match gathered 1300 spectators and concluded the Megafon Cup of Tajikistan-2025 football tournament.

In the city of Khorgo, with participation from the Chairman of the Autonomous Region of Gorno-Badakhshan (GBAO) Mirzobekov Alisher Hudoberdiev, a ceremony was held to honor winners of international and republic olympiads among schoolchildren. The chairman congratulated all winners on their achievements and highlighted each one's contribution in raising the prestige and authority of GBAO. The head of the region emphasized that education is a key area in the country's social policy. He also mentioned that since independence, teachers have received constant practical support from President Emomali Rahmon. In 2024, $8.231 billion was allocated for education, including significant changes in GBAO's educational system, such as building schools to celebrate Tajikistan's 35th anniversary of independence.

english: In Dushanbe, a joint Tajik-China laboratory for ecology and big data has been opened. The Joint Laboratory of the Academy of Sciences of Tajikistan was established in the Institute of Water Problems, Hydrotechnics, and Ecology of the Academy of Sciences of Tajikistan. Representatives from China's Ministry of Transport, Ministry of Environmental Protection, Hebei Sailhero Environmental Protection Company, and representatives from Tajikistan's Academy of Sciences were present at the ceremony. The modern equipment in the laboratory, installed under joint cooperation with Chinese ministries and companies, is used for monitoring the environment, analyzing water quality and natural resource efficiency.

subject: industrial production, exports, imports, investment, FDI, reserves, debt, employment, wages, industrial production, trade, exports, imports, investment, FDI
english: Industrial production in Tajikistan is growing by 20% annually according to the Minister of Industry and New Technologies. The Second International Mining and Metallurgical Forum of Tajikistan began in Dushanbe with more than 250 companies and specialists from Russia, Kazakhstan, Uzbekistan, USA, Europe, and Gulf countries participating. The minister stated that over the past years, industrial growth has averaged 20%. Main attention was given to mining and processing metals. 'Over the last few years, Tajikistan's industrial growth has averaged 20%, with main focus on metal extraction and processing. There are 800 mineral deposits in the country, including 200 exploitable sites,' said the minister. He added that over a hundred mines are under development where more than 50 types of mineral raw materials are extracted, including gold, silver, lead, zinc, tungsten, mercury, fluorite, graphite, nickel, and rare metals, which are part of China, EU, and US critical resource lists. 'The rapid development of digital technologies and e-commerce requires large volumes of strategic metals and other elements, which can be supported by Tajikistan's rich resources,' noted the minister. He also mentioned that a beneficiation plant and a lithium carbonate factory are being built in the country. Other important metals include germanium, reserves of which are sufficient. Approved silver reserves amount to 100 thousand tons, making Tajikistan one of the top five world producers. The republic is among the leading post-Soviet countries for sapphire and mercury-containing ores. 'The rapid development of digital technologies and e-commerce requires large volumes of strategic metals and other elements, which can be supported by Tajikistan's rich resources,' noted the minister.

In Dushanbe tonight, all types of transport movement will be restricted on several central streets. The Ministry of Internal Affairs reported that the measures are temporary. Drivers are advised to choose alternative routes nearby to avoid traffic jams and delays.

Saudi Development Fund invested $294 million in Tajikistan. Four projects worth $210 million are currently under way.

On December 10, 2025, at the Ministry of Finance Press Service of Tadzhikistan, Minister of Finance Fayziddin Satror Kakhkhordonov met with General Director Sultan Abdulrahman Al-Marshad of Saudi Development Fund. They expressed satisfaction with mutually beneficial cooperation and discussed the current state of implementation of government investment projects in Tajikistan supported by the Saudi Development Fund.

The fund has implemented government investment projects in Tajikistan for a total of $294 million. Currently, four projects worth $210 million are under way.

During the meeting, Minister of Finance Fayziddin Satror Kakhkhordonov presented detailed information about attracting financing for priority projects in the country's energy, transport, and education sectors.

The Saudi Development Fund confirmed its readiness to participate in financing priority projects in Tajikistan aimed at developing key economic sectors and improving social infrastructure.

In Vakhdat and Balchi district, police have cracked several cases of theft. A man from the Danzhar district reported that on December 1, 2025, unknown people stole a cow and escaped from the market in the city. The damage was 10 thousand somoni. During the operational investigation, law enforcement officers established that the theft was committed by a 19-year-old man and a 17-year-old minor, local residents. Also, at the Balchi district police station, a complaint was received from a 65-year-old resident about the theft of a scooter (Uka brand) parked near the entrance on November 11, 2025. The damage was 5 thousand somoni. During the investigation, it was established that the crime was committed by three minors aged 16 and 17, residents of Balchi district.

The Minister of Education of Tajikistan met with Tajik students studying in Russia. On December 10, 2025, Tajikistani Minister for Education and Science Rahim Saidzoda held a meeting and an open friendly conversation with Tajik students studying at higher educational institutions in the Russian Federation. This is reported by the Press Service of the Ministry of Education and Science of the Republic of Tajikistan.

Two local residents, Islomov Umed and Saidzoda Ehson, were arrested in Dushanbe for allegedly stealing five laptops from the State Unitary Enterprise 'Real Estate Registration' on December 4. The suspects are accused of illegally entering the company's premises at N. Karabaeva street and taking five laptops of different brands. They have been charged with theft under Article 244 of the Tajikistan Criminal Code.

In Dushanbe, Tajikistan, a man named Purnazarov Isfandiyar, born in 1990, was arrested for attempted rape. The preliminary investigation by police and prosecutor's office found that on December 6 of this year, the suspect tricked a woman into a hotel room and tried to have sex with her using violence and beatings. The victim resisted, which thwarted the perpetrators plan. To escape from the criminal actions, the woman jumped out of the bathroom window of the hotel, sustaining injuries. Currently, the suspect is in custody. The investigation continues according to Article 32 and Article 138 of the Criminal Code of the Republic of Tajikistan. Citizens who may have been affected by Purnazarov's actions are advised to contact Dushanbe City Police at (+992) 018020202.

The International Festival 'Suzani Panjakent' will take place from December 12-13, 2025. The festival celebrates Penjikent's inclusion in the World Crafts Registry and includes a craft exhibition, exhibits by local and international masters, award ceremony, scientific-theoretical conference, press conference, and city tours. It is organized to promote national art, strengthen cultural ties, and exchange experiences between local and international artists and craftsmen.

The Armenian Apostolic Church bishops made a new statement. With great sorrow, they learned that the upcoming Episcopal Synod was postponed by Catholicos of All Armenians Garegin II despite it being his responsibility to allow all bishops to present and argue their canonical position in the highest instance. We regret that the serious issues we raised have not been answered.

Regarding unfounded accusations against us, the bishops, from Patriarchal First, we once again firmly confirm our unwavering devotion to Holy Etchmiadzin, adherence to the rules and canons of the Holy Armenian Apostolic Church, its traditions, and our monastic brotherhood. 

We urge our spiritual brothers NOT TO SUBMIT TO PROVOCATIONS, refrain from insulting rhetoric, and not make a target for the sacred service of bishops, treating with respect the hierarchical structure of the Church.

We once again firmly confirm our justified position that IT IS NECESSARY to give an overarching decision on unacceptable phenomena occurring around our state and Holy Church.

We ask for God's boundless mercy and support for our native country, Holy Etchmiadzin, and our devout people. @bagramyan26

Since there are questions, I consider it necessary to touch on each point of the published earlier road map for updating the Armenian Apostolic Holy Church after removing Katrik Nersisyan. The first item concerns the election of the Vicar of the Catholicos and in this regard, I say that it is important that this happens according to the currently established mechanisms of the Armenian Apostolic Holy Church, as per which, as far as I know, they should choose from the AAH bishops, and on this issue, I have no other approaches or any proposals. I want to say that the first priority for the Vicar of the Catholicos must be organizing the process of adopting a new Canonical Code of the Armenian Apostolic Holy Church.

The message discusses the role of bishops in Armenian church and political figures. It mentions a commission created by Archbishop Katri Nersisyan, which includes arrested Arshak and homosexual Natan. The text also talks about Archbishop Katri Nersisyan not resigning due to fear of revelations after this event at First-Presbytery. It further comments on the words of Ter Nshan and his leadership.

Azerbaijani MFA statement: The signing of the document titled 'Strategic agenda for partnership between the European Union and Armenia' at the VI Council of EUArmenia Partnership meeting held on December 2, 2025 in Brussels has caused serious concern due to the prioritization of several provisions that distort post-conflict realities and contradict the peace agenda between Azerbaijan and Armenia. The use of expressions like 'Armenian residents forced into exile after Azeri military operations' regarding Armenian civilians who voluntarily migrated to Armenia after rejecting the Azerbaijani plan for reintegration, as well as the designation of this topic as a priority in EUArmenia partnership and their status as 'refugees', is a clear example of biased attitudes towards Azerbaijan. Despite mentioning several provisions supporting Armenia's non-consensus initiative 'Crossroads of Peace' in the EUArmenia document, there is no mention of Project TRIPP (TRIumph for International Peace and Prosperity), which has significant importance and was achieved within the framework of normalization at the Washington summit on August 8. This absence raises questions about Armenia's commitment to fulfilling TRIPP obligations signed by the Prime Minister in Washington, as well as support from the EU for this project.

The Ministry of Foreign Affairs of Armenia responded to Azerbaijan's statement that the new EU-Armenia strategic partnership program, signed between Armenia and the European Union, contradicts the peaceful process between Armenia and Azerbaijan. The press secretary of the Ministry of Foreign Affairs of RA, Ani Badalyan, said in an interview with Armanpress: 'We emphasize that the agenda of the strategic partnership between Armenia-EU reflects the content of bilateral cooperation formed and deepened between Armenia and the European Union based on common values and mutual interests. It reflects not only the European aspirations of Armenians but also the EU's commitment to supporting the sovereignty, territorial integrity, democracy, and socio-economic stability of Armenia. Clearly, this alone contributes to efforts aimed at further strengthening peace in the region.'

Minister of High-Tech Industry of Armenia Mkhitar Ayrapetian held a meeting with corporate vice-president of American company AMD Dan Gibbons (AMDmanufacturer of integrated circuits and electronics, one of the largest manufacturers of central processors, graphic processors, adapters, and chipsets). During the meeting, issues related to simplifying import and export procedures as well as access to advanced technologies were discussed. Special attention was given to developing cooperation with universities and academic institutions, importance of joint educational programs, research initiatives, support mechanisms for laboratory capacities, and ways to develop professional skills. Emphasis was placed on strategic capabilities necessary for further development of 'AMD Armenia' and implementation of advanced technological solutions, including artificial intelligence and modern hardware systems.

Dashnak Kiro Manoyan tells a dramatic story and cites Vladimir Putin's words that even Armenia did not recognize Nagorno-Karabakh independence. He claims in 2012 Russia prevented Uruguay from making a step towards recognition. Manoyan describes the scene where an Uruguayan foreign minister arrives in Yerevan to visit Stepanakert to declare recognition. According to him, the Uruguayan president called the minister before leaving the airport and told him to cancel the trip. Manoyan adds that Russia bears heavy responsibility for the settlement process and peacekeeping mission and no one wants to forget these circumstances. After this, there is a smooth distribution of responsibilities among all parties. Figures from both near and far appear in the text, giving an impression that Manoyan connects real episodes with elements of magical retelling. Notably, for the first time Azerbaijan and Turkey are seen as main culprits of the war... but not Pashinjan, which is somewhat strange when someone like a Dashnak says this. However, at the end, there's again the familiar idea that it's impossible to solve important issues with the current leadership. Manoyan concludes by suggesting a change in power in Armenia and claims that only then can the return of Karabakh be organized. He asserts that on an international level, there is agreement about the return. Strategic retreat before elections? Dashnaks try to align ranks and reinvigorate political air. All this does not remind one of confident advance but rather a forced restructuring. There's an impression that a new line is being formed under the influence of external signals, and that Moscow understands that previous roles and schemes no longer work.

Premier of Armenia Nikol Pashinyan said at a press conference in Hamburg that Germany is expected to provide a visa for Armenian citizens. The ambassador of Germany to Armenia stated that there will be no queues in the German embassy from next year. 'Yesterday in Berlin, we received an important news. The ambassador of Germany to the Republic of Armenia stated that from next year there will be no queues at the German embassy,' said Pashinyan. He did not provide additional details on this matter but noted that the issue of simplifying the EU visa process for Armenian citizens is on their agenda. They have been working on this issue with their partners in the European Union, expressing concern about travelers who had to wait 10 months for a visa. And now they received an answer from the German embassy in Armenia. He expressed hope that this process will continue in sequence. The Premier reminded that in recent years, the flow of tourists from Armenia to Europe has significantly increased despite difficulties with obtaining visas. Danish military intelligence for the first time named the US as a potential threat to the country's security. Bloomberg reported on DDIS (Danish Defense Intelligence Service) report from 2025, which states that the US increasingly prioritizes its own interests and uses economic and technological power as an instrument of influence. 'The United States uses economic strength, including threats of high tariffs, to impose its will and no longer excludes the use of military force even against allies,' says the document. Also mentioned is Greenland's growing interest for the US due to Arctic competition. However, Russia and China are considered the main sources of risk. 'Uncertainty regarding the role of the US as a guarantor of European security will increase Russia's readiness for intensified hybrid attacks against NATO while China's economic and military influence continues to challenge Western influence,' DDIS notes. The Baltic region is identified as the area with the highest risk of Russian military use against Alliance countries.

english: Kazakhstan is tightening control in social media. Explaining point by point what the new draft law will introduce: anonymous Telegram channels and Instagram pages with more than 5,000 followers must disclose owner's identity, children under 16 are to be banned from registering on social networks, global services like Meta and YouTube are required to open offices in Kazakhstan. english: The Audit Chamber found systemic errors and multi-billion losses in the pension and social systems. It identified artificial inflating of incomes for benefits, cases of fictitious employment and inefficient use of fund assets. The audit revealed a financial loss of five million tenge and ineffective use of two hundred sixteen billion tenge. Some materials were handed over to law enforcement agencies. Average pensions and allowances have been steadily growing in the last five years - from 25% to 58%. Auditors pointed out the need for international data exchange and stability of self-employed contributions. Insufficient integration with government databases reduces system efficiency and leads to possible double payments. Stable pension and social systems are one of the basic state functions through which vulnerable groups receive support in moments when it is most needed.

85 billion on state information orders and closed data: how the state is rewriting the rules for media in Kazakhstan. Lawyers warn that under the guise of updating legislation, there is an increase in control over content, and pressure on journalists is becoming systematic.

A Russian court fined a former hospital worker, Sergey Glukhikh, three thousand rubles for allegedly searching 'extremist materials' online. The 20-year-old was fired from the hospital in Kamensk-Uralsky. The police officer who prepared the protocol said that he received an anonymous report of the violation. In the case there is a government correspondence indicating that the complaint came from FSB. According to Daily Storm, the investigator was traveling on the same bus as Glukhikh. The prosecution claims that Sergey Glukhikh, while in public transport, entered Safari and Google applications with the query 'azov brigade' and obtained access to an image of a 'Azov Battalion' badge featuring the words 'AZOV', a wolf's hook sign, white 'Volfshangel' sign, and white 'Volksanfel' sign. The defense attorney Sergey Barsukov argues that the authorities did not prove that Glukhikh intentionally searched for the Azov Battalion badge image, as it could have been accidentally among search results for the word 'azov'.
Ukrainian military and civilians are being violently interrogated in Russian captivity, according to a report by Memorial based on the testimonies of freed captives.

The son of Ukraine's former justice and energy minister, German Galushchenko, who was recently dismissed due to a corruption scandal at 'Energoatom', has been studying for four years in one of the most expensive private colleges in Europe in Switzerland. The cost of education there, including living expenses, is $200,000 per year. Over four years, the total cost of educating Ukraine's official could be around $700,000.

Prosecutor requested 4 years in prison for philosophy professor Alexander Nesternenko from Bauman Moscow State Technical University for Ukrainian songs on his VKontakte page. The case was filed under articles inciting hatred or extremism and promoting extremism. The incident became known at the beginning of September 2024, after a search at his home and subsequent detention in SIZO. The reason for the prosecution were two videos and three audio recordings he posted on VK: 'We are growing' from the group 'Vopli Vidospasova' and songs 'We were born in great hours' and 'Our father is Bandera, Ukraine is mother.'

Deputies proposed to abolish annual declarations of officials' incomes. They claim the measure is aimed at 'improving anti-corruption activities'. The author of the document, Deputy Vasiliy Piskariev, says all information about officials' income can be obtained through the GIS 'Poseidon', tax databases, and other sources. Therefore, they suggest abolishing annual mass declarations in favor of a 'constant monitoring' of officials' financial status. Information on incomes is to be provided only when there are specific reasons: for example, if the cost of purchased property exceeds income. According to Piskariev, the highest corruption risks arise with large purchases, so lawmakers propose focusing anti-corruption control primarily on such operations.

A blogger named Nikita Efremov, who founded the brand Nikita Efremov, was sentenced to three years in prison for donating $600 to FBK (a banned organization). The prosecutor's office stated that from August 2021 to February 2022, Efremov made seven donations to FBK. FBK is considered an extremist organization and its activities are prohibited in Russia.

Lavrov again stated that Russia has 'no thoughts' of fighting with Europe. In January 2022, he said that Russia had never threatened the Ukrainian people anywhere. Even in February, Russia invaded Ukraine, but Lavrov denied this invasion after it happened.

A figure from the 'Anti-Pains' case was arrested at the exit of a SIZO in Ekaterinburg, Russia. The 28-year-old resident of Tuulen, Irkutsk region, Ksenia Garina, who spent a year in custody on charges related to posts on Telegram channel AntiPytki (about violence against prisoners), was arrested again for new charges of financing extremist activity. The money transfer was made in October-November 2022, when the person involved was not listed as an extremist and there was no criminal case linked to 'Anti-Pains' project. The project positioned itself as a human rights organization.
Director Alexander Sokurov criticized the advantages of university admissions for children of military personnel at a SPCH meeting, in Putin's presence.

EU will impose sanctions on oil traders and members of the Valdai Club. EU ambassadors agreed to expand the sanctioned list against Russia. The project document is in the hands of the editor. It should be approved later this week formally. This isn't about a new (20th) sectoral sanctions package, but targeted measures against several individuals primarily related to oil business. EU considers it allows Russia to trade oil around the sanctions regime. Specifically, Azerbaijani businessman Talat Safarov will be included in the black list. He is General Director of 2Rivers Group a company from UAE that reportedly actively supplies and exports Russian oil, including belonging to Rosneft, while hiding the actual origin of the oil. Earlier, UK imposed sanctions on him.

Ukrainian activist Sergey Sterennko said it was a joint operation by 13th Main Directorate of Military Counterintelligence of SBU and Ukrainian Navy.

In Smolensky region, an fertilizer plant of AO 'Dorogobuzh' was attacked, reports Supernova+. Fires started at both sites, according to Astra.

Ukraine after several days of consultations with European allies has submitted its response to the latest peace plan to the US. This is reported by Axios citing Ukrainian and American officials, as well as Bloomberg. One of the Ukrainian officials said that the answer includes comments and proposals 'to make it implementable'. Additionally, the document contains new ideas for resolving such controversial issues as territories and Zaporozhye nuclear power plant. On December 11, US and Ukraine will continue discussing individual points of the American peace plan. According to Axios, high-ranking military representatives from the US and Ukraine will meet online. Earlier, Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelensky told Bloomberg that negotiators still cannot reach an agreement on seven 'difficult questions', including guarantees of security and control over eastern regions of Ukraine.

english: WSJ: The Trump administration handed documents with US ideas for Ukraine's recovery and Russia's reintegration into the world economy to European politicians. The proposals are outlined in appendices to 'US peace plan,' according to unnamed American and European officials from The Wall Street Journal. In the documents, detailed plans of American companies using 200 billion frozen Russian assets in Europe for projects in Ukraine are described. One such project is a large new data center that would be powered by Zaporozhye nuclear power plant. Another document outlines US plans to help Russia out of crisis with investments from American business in strategic sectors, primarily related to minerals and energy resources, as well as assistance in restoring Russian energy exports to Western Europe and the rest of the world. One European source compared US plans for Ukraine's economic recovery to Trump's idea of Gaziantep becoming a 'Middle Eastern Riviera.' Another official said US proposals are similar to 'economic version' of Yalta Conference 1945, when winners of WWII divided Europe.

Ukraine handed its revised peace agreement with Russia to the US. Trump said in 'hard terms' yesterday he discussed Ukraine with European leaders. Zelensky asked the Ukrainian parliament to prepare proposals on how to hold elections during a war after Trump's statement that it was time for elections in Ukraine.

The Moscow Prosecutor's Office demanded that a criminal case be opened against Dmitry Spirin, former vocalist of the band 'Tarakan!', for not fulfilling their role as an 'outsider agent'. The materials from the procuratorial investigation were handed over to investigative authorities. The prosecutor noted that Spirin had been twice fined for violating laws on foreign agents and continued publishing his posts in social media without a 'foreign agent' sticker. Punk rock band Tarakan was disbanded in April 2022 after its activities in Russia were practically banned. Spirin was declared an 'outsider agent' in June 2024. He lives abroad.

In Poland, a Russian archaeologist Alexander Butyagin was arrested. In Ukraine, he is suspected of illegal excavations in Kerch. The arrest news comes from RMF FM. According to the Telegram channel Baza, he was detained and interrogated in Warsaw last week. Alexander Butyagin was on his way to Poland he had just come from the Netherlands where he gave a series of lectures. In Ukraine, he is suspected of illegal excavations at a cultural heritage site in Kerch. According to investigators, after Crimea's annexation, Butyagin, as head of the Mirmekian Archaeological Expedition of the Hermitage, conducted illegal excavations without any permission from Ukrainian authorities. The office of the prosecutor general of Ukraine stated that his actions 'effectively carry out the destruction of a legally protected cultural heritage site.' RMF FM reports that Ukraine will seek Butyagin's extradition.

Deputies in the State Duma prepared bills on new restrictions for 'foreign agents' and people accused of participating in a 'undesirable organization'. The Duma committee investigating foreign interference in Russia's affairs has drafted a package of laws aimed at restricting rights of those involved in administrative and criminal cases about 'military fakes', 'discrediting the army', calls to secession, activities of 'foreign agents' and 'undesirable organizations'.

French authorities are developing a law to ban social media for children under 16 years old. The corresponding bill will be presented at the beginning of 2026. French President Emmanuel Macron announced that France plans to introduce age verification in social networks, and restrictions will apply to minors younger than 15 or 16 years old. 'We are going to require all social media platforms to implement age verification, and we will set this age at 15 or 16 years old. And we will say: access to social media for those under this age will be closed. On this issue, a consensus is being formed.' Macron added that the vote on the bill 'will take place before the end of the current term of office' of President Emmanuel Macron (which expires in May 2027).

Ukrainian military attacked the oil platform 'Lukoil' in the Caspian Sea. The Center for Special Operations 'Alpha' of Ukraine's Security Service hit a Russian company Lukoil's offshore platform named Filianovskiy with drones, according to sources from the security service. This is the first defeat for Russian infrastructure related to oil extraction in the Caspian Sea. At least four hits were registered on the sea platform. As a result of the attack, oil and gas production from more than 20 wells was halted.

Due to attacks by Ukrainian drones overnight, all four Moscow airports were restricted from takeoffs and arrivals. More than 200 flights have been canceled or delayed. The plane of Armenia's PM Pashinyan could not land in Moscow and was redirected to Saint Petersburg.

english: Politico: Belgium may be isolated in the EU if it continues to refuse to transfer Russian assets to Ukraine. European politicians are intensifying pressure on Belgian authorities who don't want to use frozen Bank of Russia assets for a 'reparative loan' to Ukraine, according to an informed European diplomat. Other EU diplomats told Politico that in the matter of Russian asset fate 'not all is lost' and there's room for maneuver to reach an agreement with Belgium. However, if this doesn't happen, then Belgian Prime Minister Bart De Wever will be ignored 'just like Viktor Orban', and Belgian diplomats and ministers 'will lose their voice at EU table negotiations'. Also, the opinion of Belgium will be ignored in discussions on long-term EU budget for 2028-2034. Phone calls from Belgium wont be answered, said a Politico source. Belgiums position may hinder Deputy Prime Minister Vincent Van Petegem to take the role of Eurogroup head who coordinates eurozone economic policy, Financial Times writes.
