The Bulgarian government has resigned due to mass protests. Prime Minister Rosen Zhelyazkov announced the cabinet's resignation in response to widespread protests in the country, as reported by Radio Free Europe. The protesters demanded a government change. Today, parliament planned to vote on a no-confidence motion against the government. In recent weeks, large-scale demonstrations have been held across the country demanding a government change. The protest was triggered by the budget proposal for 2026 presented by ruling parties, but citizens are also dissatisfied with corruption and opaque management practices.

Hackers broke into the infrastructure of the developer of the unified conscription registry. The Ministry of Defense denies the hack.

An anonymous hacker group hacked the website of key developer Mikord, a project called 'Idite Les' obtained a large number of documents from the hackers.

"Thanks to the hack, the development of the Registry was canceled for at least several months. Another few months this scam (30 million accounts!) will not be able to send people to kill and die," says the post 'Idite Les'.

The authenticity of the documents, as well as Mikord's involvement in developing the registry, were confirmed by the publication 'Important Stories'. Director of Mikord Ramil Gabdrahmanov confirmed journalists that a hack occurred, saying that 'now many attacks are being made.'

The Ministry of Defense of Russia called the false statements about allegedly hacking the conscription registry not corresponding to reality. The ministry claims that the Registry is operating in normal mode and all hacker attacks have been successfully stopped.

Hacker breached the infrastructure of Russia's unified conscription registry registration system developer. The Ministry of Defense denies hacking. According to Zelensky, the decision should remain for Ukrainian people: 'I believe that on this question, the answer will be given by Ukraine's people. Also Zelensky confirmed that the document includes Russia leaving occupied territories of Kharkiv, Sumskaya and Dnipropetrovsk oblasts. In Kherson and Zaporozhie oblasts, a line of contact is proposed for division. A person cannot exit Russian citizenship or obtain a passport abroad. english:
DPK "Ak Zhol": "Today in Kazakhstan's labor market serious changes are emerging that require a systemic response from the state and a change in regulatory approaches. There is an annual increase in the number of legal entities... Overall this is a positive trend, but such rapid growth raises doubts about whether MSB has quality permanent jobs for workers.

The State is launching large infrastructure projects - construction of TEC, three nuclear power plants, development of green energy, development of utilities and transportation network. The quick implementation of the project will require thousands of specialists, and local resources may not be enough.

According to the forecast of the Center for Development of Labor Resources, from 2025 to 2035, the total demand for hired workers is estimated at 3 million people in the base scenario. Of these, 813 thousand are for working positions. The greatest need is expected in industry (27%) and construction (11%).

At the same time, the level of wages in Kazakhstan remains the highest among Central Asian countries and significantly exceeds regional averages.

Today in Kazakhstan there are enough jobs, especially in the service sector, construction and agriculture.

However, we observe a global trend of closure of borders and strengthening protectionism in Europe and Russia, as well as tightening visa rules. 
The DPK "Akzhol" faction believes that on the background of mass migration of labor migrants from neighboring countries, Kazakhstan needs to attract labor migrants from fraternal Central Asian republics.

However, migration flows must be managed strategically with an emphasis on qualifications, taxes and integration, so they will become a source of economic growth and social stability. At the same time, it is important that the economic benefits remain in the country."
New appointments and dismissals in the President's administration, KGEK MEC, AO 'Fund for the development of industry'

At the Government, with participation of First Deputy Prime Minister Roman Sklyar, a signing ceremony took place for cooperation agreement between AO 'Ust-Kamenogorsk Armature Plant' (AO 'UKAZ') and AO 'Caspian Pipeline ConsortiumK' (AO 'CTK-K'). Cooperation is aimed at developing local production of valve equipment, pump units, and electric motors, expanding the use of domestic equipment on pipeline infrastructure projects, and forming a stable partnership between Kazakhstan's largest producer of pipeline equipment and one of the key operators in the oil transportation infrastructure.

Under the leadership of Deputy Prime Minister and Minister of Culture and Information Aida Balayev, a meeting was held to prepare for the education system. The deputy PM reported on the main directions and results of implementing the Concept of Development of Pedagogical Education, as well as analytical conclusions from the international study Teaching and Learning International Survey (TALIS) conducted by OECD, which reflected both positive developments in the modernization process of teacher training over the past three years and its shortcomings, including inadequate preparation of teachers and educators within universities on one hand and school graduates on the other. Aida Balayev highlighted the reasons for the current situation, particularly the lack of effective inter-ministerial cooperation between ministries, akims, and universities. She noted that only a coordinated and systemic approach can ensure schools have necessary specialists and effectively resolve the issue of labor shortage in regions, primarily due to inadequate market analysis. 'The deficit of personnel needs to be corrected by region. Where possible, faculty admissions should increase. If we lack subject experts, for example mathematicians then grants are needed. Universities must align with the job market. Here, significant changes may occur in the near future as some professions become obsolete due to AI development. Considering this, universities and schools need to work on real market needs.' She also highlighted practical orientation of pedagogical education. 'Theory without practice is useless: a specialist's knowledge only works when applied. All universities must have equal opportunities for student practice. But this requires clear planning. Today, we prepare future teachers but young specialists leaving the field exacerbates the shortage problem. To solve this issue, we need to unite efforts. Now more than ever, inter-ministerial cooperation is important. Remember that our common goals and tasks are shared.' Summarizing, Deputy Prime Minister outlined several specific tasks and protocol instructions, emphasizing their timely execution.

Over the years of independence, the number of Kazakhstani ambassadors has changed significantly in Russia (13). On second place is Austria and Belarus (11 each). Third place is the US, Turkmenistan, and Uzbekistan (10 each). Fourth place is UN, Belgium, India, Iran, Turkey, France (9 each). Fifth place is Azerbaijan, UK, Egypt, Israel, China, Kyrgyzstan, Lithuania, Malaysia, Poland, Ukraine, Germany, Switzerland, South Korea (8 each). Currently there are vacancies for ambassadors in the UK and Afghanistan. Staying at their posts: 8 have been working since 2021, 15 since 2022, 12 since 2023, 19 since 2024, and 21 since 2025. Currently Kazakhstan has 77 embassies (excluding those without permanent leaders), while in 1992 there were only 5. Over the years, 223 people have served as ambassadors, including 52 who served twice, 31 three times, and 15 four times (Umarov and Kazan) and 1 who served five times (Abdrahmanov). Three ambassadors had children who also became ambassadors. Interestingly, out of 14 foreign ministers over the years, 5 did not have experience as an ambassador. Three held the position twice. Three were simultaneously vice premiers.

Gossovetsman Eral Karin held a traditional meeting on strengthening inter-ethnic harmony. This time, reports came from Jambyl and Turkestan regions - special control areas. It was the sixth such meeting this year on national issues. Regularly similar events take place to implement President's messages, internal policy, child safety, school education training. Such format keeps hot topics under control, monitors regional situations, and keeps central state organs in shape. This is besides traditional load of meetings with UNESCO, overseas cadre preparation, anti-corruption Council, Youth Council. Karin is responsible for close interaction with ideological blocks from Moscow, Beijing, Tashkent, and Bishkek. This year, 'Main Principles, Values and Directions of Internal Policy of the Republic of Kazakhstan' were developed and approved. The ideological block, under constant criticism from radicals on both sides, energetically carries out meticulous work to maintain stability and harmony, prevent provocations, protect and nurture the next generation.

The Kazakhstani railway was criticized. The chairman of the board, Talgat Aldybergenov, got confused in a complex formulation and passed the question to his deputy. Social media immediately raised a fuss about the professionalism of the top management of the national company.

Although the situation is not very pleasant, no one really asked for reasons. As far as known, Aldybergenov had tense negotiations with Tashkent before the meeting regarding increasing train exchanges and expanding the reception of grains and food products through the Sarayogash junction. He returned to Astana quite late in the morning and was at the press briefing, which was his second appearance before the media. Moreover, it was about KZTJ debts, on which traditionally a traditional response is made diplomatically.

The reason for irony is given, but regarding lack of professionalism can be disputed.
KZTJ has shown good dynamics in recent years - both economic and production.
Recently, the second track of Dostyk-Moyinty was launched. The oblique line Jetygen-Kazibek Bek is under construction, which will reduce the load on Almaty junction by 40%. The line Darbaz-Maktaral is being built to relieve the station Sarayogash. Active work is underway on the Bakhty-Ayaqoz - third railway crossing with China, which radically improves cargo delivery in Northern Kazakhstan and Russia. The project of road Moyinty-Kyzylzhar - optimization of logistics and unloading of the Moyinty-Jar route is being implemented.
KZTJ now pulls both intraregional logistics, export of Kazakh products, implementation of transit corridors North-South and West-East (TMTE), and digitalization of the entire system.
And he gets used to communication with the media.

subject: taxes, budget, deficit
english: Uzbekistan plans to introduce a cashback for purchasing real estate on the primary market. The government will consider returning part of the VAT paid by citizens as a cashback when buying residential and non-residential premises in new multi-apartment buildings through banks. The Ministry of Economic Development, Tax Committee, and Ministry of Construction must submit a corresponding proposal to the Cabinet of Ministers by February 1, 2026.

subject: reserves, current account, budget, deficit
english: For new banks in Kyrgyzstan that haven't submitted documents by January 1st, they will have to form capital of at least 5 billion soms. The National Bank suggested tightening rules for new banks: if the draft resolution is adopted, all institutions submitting applications after January 1, 2026 will need a minimum UAA of 5 billion soms (currently 1 billion). For existing banks, the increase will be gradual to 5 billion by 2030. For systemically important ones, it will be immediately 8 billion from 2026.

subject: inflation, growth
english: The Asian Development Bank revised its inflation and GDP forecasts for Kazakhstan. In September, the bank predicted an inflation rate of 10.5%. In December, it adjusted this to 11.2%. At the same time, the bank also revised the GDP growth from 5.3% to 5.8%. For next year, the ADB expects inflation around 9.5% (instead of 8.4%), and GDP growth at 4.5% (instead of 5%).

Constitutional Court of Kyrgyzstan blocked the president's idea to reintroduce capital punishment. American satellites have detected the largest methane leaks in Turkmenistan. Kazakhstan will produce equipment for KTK. By year-end, Uzbek-Ukrainian tech park plans to launch another 8 projects worth $75 million, creating around 1000 new jobs. New Kyrgyz parliament members will register and vote using fingerprints. In recent years, trade between Kyrgyzstan and Russia has increased by 2.5 times, while exports have grown by 4.5 times. In Uzbekistan, producers of cotton and grain will be given ratings. The best will receive low-interest loans. In Dushanbe, the National Water Council held its first meeting.

Azeri publication Minval Politika claims Baku is discussing the possibility of restoring a rail line to Armenia's border 'in response to Tbilisi's tariff protest.' Earlier, this publication reported that Georgia demanded an unjustified high transit fee for Azeri fuel in Armenia. Then Gruzian PM Iakob Khaidze said they would provide free one-time transit of oil products. But such temporary solutions don't address the main question: what is Georgia's real position regarding long-term tariffs and customs duties? The publication cites 'sources well acquainted with discussions between Baku and Yerevan' that Azeri has already started assessing its own capabilities to form an alternative logistics axis. This involves restoring a rail line that in Soviet times connected Baku with Gazakh, then heading towards Ijevan.

Georgian Prime Minister Iakob Khabagidze commented on the construction of a customs terminal in Galsky district of de facto Republic of Abkhazia, near Ingur Bridge. He called the information about possible Georgian participation in the project 'speculation'.

We do not recognize any so-called state border, it is complete lies, and based on this, there can be no discussion. Previously, under previous administration, a specific agreement was signed, which allowed Russia to join WTO, and then an agreement was reached that with Swiss mediation, the possibility of transporting goods should be created. However, since then, this issue has been suspended, and our side did not take any steps in this direction. Based on this, everything is speculation. The Law on Occupied Territories is in effect, and the government does not have any initiatives in this area.

He said at a briefing, answering to the corresponding question.

Azerbaijan continues to criticize Georgia's tariff policy. The publication 'Minval', which already expressed dissatisfaction with Tbilisi's logistics services, published an article warning Georgia about the possibility of resuming direct rail communication with Armenia in case of continued current tariff policies by Tbilisi. Objective from subjective and political from economic separated in Director Paata Tsagareishvili of the Transport Corridor Center Research.

In Moscow clinic, the second victim of a shooting in Sukhumi on November 11 died. The 45-year-old resident of Sukhum, Almas Kviciqia, had severe cranial-meningeal trauma. He was previously taken to Russia for treatment. Sadly, he passed away today at the National Medical Research Center Neurosurgery named after Academician Burdenko. More / Echo Caucasus

A restaurant manager in Orenburg, Georgia and Vano (Nino&Vano), was fined 150 thousand rubles for defacing religious objects. The case involved leaflets with images of the Moscow Church of St. Basil the Blessed instead of cupolas, which were considered a direct desecration of holy sites. The prosecutor interviewed an Orthodox church representative in Orenburg. The court stated that since the Church of St. Basil is an active church, the depiction on the leaflet was 'a direct desecration of the holy site.'

The protest movement in Georgia has entered a post-election period without a unified strategy to document alleged fraud, coordinate long-term mobilization or develop an convincing model of transitional governance. This lack of leadership and clear direction undermined public trust and limited the ability of the movement to transform dissatisfaction into organized political pressure.
quotes US President Donald Trump's new security strategy and comments on the tension between European leaders and their American counterparts. Critics link Gru... Read more / Echo Kavkaz

Israeli lawmakers canceled their trip to Georgia, planned for the upcoming weekend, due to threats of terrorism. The parliamentarians were supposed to participate in events during 'Israel Week' in Georgia, including a Georgian-Israeli business forum. President of the Georgian-Israeli Business Chamber and founder of 'The House of Israel', Icyk Moshe, confirmed that 'Israel Week' will still take place in Tbilisi, but lawmakers may join remotely. Moshe also stated that information about the threat was passed to the Georgian side. He assured that security measures for the event would be ensured. 'We have no fear,' said Moshe, adding that Israel has been in a state of war for several years.

Echo Caucasus reported: 'According to Georgian security services, neither Georgian nor Israeli intelligence had any information about possible terrorist threats in Georgia. As a result, they did not share this information with anyone. We are in contact with representatives of the Israeli intelligence service who expressed surprise at the spread of incorrect information. It is very sad and indicative that such information is being disseminated by part of the Georgian media without verification from us. We strongly urge everyone to refrain from spreading damaging information to Georgia.'

Georgian Prime Minister Irakli Kobakhidze went to Turkmenistan for participation in an international forum on the International Year of Peace and Trust, which celebrates 30 years of Turkmenistan's neutrality. Earlier this year, Kobakhidze visited Turkmenistan twice. The official visit took place from March 4-5, during which he met with President Serdar Berdymukhamedov and agreements were signed in various fields. In August, the prime minister participated in the Third Conference of the UN for countries without access to the sea, held in Avaza, Turkmenistan.

The Liberal-Democratic Alliance (ALDE), one of the largest political forces in the European Parliament, reacted to Speaker Shalva Papuaishvili's recent statements calling for distancing themselves from opposition politician Aleko Eliashvili. 'Of course, liberal democrats do not justify these actions as is obvious. Just as we never justified violence against peaceful protesters or the use of chemical weapons against civilians,' says ALDE, published on social network X.

European Court of Human Rights (ECtHR) in Strasbourg confirmed violations of several articles of the European Convention on Human Rights in the case about dispersing a protest in Tbilisi from June 20-21, 2019. According to the decision published on December 11, Georgian authorities should pay hundreds of thousands of euros (over 640 thousand euros as material and non-material compensation) to those affected by 'Gavrilov's night' and additional up to 40 thousand euros for covering court expenses.

The plane carrying Armenia's Prime Minister Nikol Pashinyan, which was heading to Moscow in the night of Thursday due to airspace closure caused by Ukrainian unmanned aircraft attacks, could not land in Russia. The information was confirmed by Pashinyan's press service.

Abkhazian parliament deputies on December 10th, in the second and final reading, introduced amendments to the 'Property Registry Law', according to which it will come into force from July 1, 2027. As previously reported by Echo of Caucasus, the law was supposed to address a long-standing problem that arose after the war of the 1990s. Many houses remained without legal owners, buildings were occupied illegally, and disputes around property often escalated into conflicts. Attempts to create clear legislation in the field of real estate ownership had been made over two decades but none of them was completed. When the law finally took effect, there were demands to postpone it, change it or even cancel it.
Georgy Ghazaryan's former ministry of internal affairs party agrees with the Strasbourg court decision on the dispersal of the Mayakovsky night demonstration.

Georgian Prime Minister Irakli Kobakhidze met with Turkmen President Serdar Berdymukhamedov in Ashgabat. The sides discussed deepening political and economic cooperation, developing transit-logistics routes, and the potential for attracting additional cargo through the Middle Corridor to Georgian ports.

Kobakhidze confirmed Georgia's readiness to assist in transporting Turkmen gas through its territory and thanked Turkmenistan for supporting Georgia's territorial integrity. He invited Berdymukhamedov to visit Tbilisi on an official visit.

Kobakhidze also met with Azeri Prime Minister Ali Asadov. The talks covered strategic partnership between the two countries, growth in trade-economic cooperation, and implementation of regional projects.

Earlier, the Kremlin reported that Vladimir Putin would also visit Ashgabat from December 11-12. It is expected that Russian President will hold bilateral meetings with foreign leaders, including with Turkish President Recep Tayyip Erdogan. Armenian President Vahagn Hakobyan has also arrived in Turkmenistan.

A new Georgian ambassador to the US, Tamara Taliashvili, has been linked to Moscow. The focus is now on her husband: a Russian-linked law firm in his name provides support to sanctioned Russian companies. This is a signal from Georgia's government that it will remain Russia's de facto client state.

subject: debt, exports, imports, investment, FDI, industrial production, trade
english: Over the next five years, the oil and gas industry can save more than $320 billion through further digitalization of operations in five key areas: optimizing drilling, autonomous robotics, predictive maintenance, managing fields, and logistics optimization. This forecast was made by Rystad Energy. Also mentioned is that widespread implementation of digital systems in the oil and gas sector faces significant obstacles including substantial initial costs for equipment, software, ongoing maintenance, and cybersecurity. These obstacles are especially acute for small companies or those working with outdated infrastructure.

english: Ula Borten Mu, who served as Norway's Minister of Petroleum and Energy from 2011 to 2013 and the Minister of Higher Education in Stre's cabinet, will lead Norsk Kjernekraft, which plans to build small modular nuclear power plants. The company is being financed by billionaire Trond Mohn. It has informed the Norwegian Radiation and Nuclear Safety Authority about its plans. Funding for projects will be provided through cooperation with major industrial consumers. Specifically, it plans to create a project development company together with Swedish Blykalla on Svalbard. Norsk Kjernekraft also signed with Aecon, GE Vernova Hitachi BWRX-300's main contractor in Canada. Canadians are actively signing up for projects. By the way, in 2011, Future in Our Hands recognized Ula Borten Mu and Staty as laureates of the annual anti-premium award for the most unethical actions 'rets Etikkversting'. For implementing and actively lobbying shale oil extraction projects in the US and Canada, respectively.

Ukraine extended until January 17, 2026, the license that allows negotiations and conditional agreements with Lukoil International GmbH or any controlled company. Previously, Britain postponed sanctions against Lukoil International to February 26, 2026.

subject: exports, imports, investment, FDI
english: To solve the problem of a saturated market, large Chinese producers of quantum dots created a company to remove small players from the market. Beijing Guanghe Qiancheng Technology was registered in Beijing on December 9 with assets of 3 billion ($424.7 million). The new company has 10 shareholders. Earlier it was reported that industry leaders plan to create a structure similar to OPEC with financial capabilities of 50 billion for buying and closing quantum dot production capacities up to at least 1 million tons. In October, it was reported that self-discipline helped Chinese producers of quantum dots to exit the crisis.

US Navy seized a sanctioned Venezuelan oil tanker off its shores. Piracy continues today. Most of Venezuela's oil is supplied to China. Today, the Nobel Peace Prize was awarded to Maria Corina Machado, daughter of a Venezuelan opposition politician. She couldn't attend the ceremony. Earlier she said that Venezuela should privatize the oil industry and transfer natural resources to the US.

english: Expansion of the French nuclear power plant park faced unexpected problems. The Lyon Administrative Court overturned changes in documents related to urban planning that would have allowed two new nuclear reactors on the 'Bugey' site. After a hearing on November 18, the court ruled in favor of anti-nuclear group Sortir du nuclaire Bugey and several local residents. They claim the impact assessment for the project is insufficient and was conducted improperly. Owners of the Bugey nuclear power plant, companies EDF and RTE, plan to build two more by 2040. The municipality and plant owners will appeal the court decision.

Minister of Energy Sergey Tseiliev said that the government is considering lifting the ban on exporting gasoline and diesel, which will depend on market conditions. The market is currently stable. On December 15, Vice Premier Alexander Novak will hold another meeting about the oil products market.

subject: exports, imports, energy production, energy consumption, electricity prices, renewable energy sources
english: Germany will cover almost 56% of its electricity consumption in 2025 through renewables. However, this negatively affects reliability and electricity prices. Too much renewable energy is not good. Also, total electricity production may fall again. This is a worrying indicator.
Scammers masquerade as energy company messages. Woman fell for scam, transferred money to a fake crypto wallet. Next day, all her accounts were drained of 186 thousand rubles.

Tajikistani parliament approved amendments to the Criminal Code, toughening penalties for illegal cryptocurrency mining. A new article #253(2) Illegal use of electricity for virtual asset production will be added. For violations related to illegally using electricity for crypto mining, a fine from $1650 to $4070 is imposed. Grouping and large-scale violation can result in a fine from $4125 to $8250 or imprisonment from 2 to 5 years. Theft of electricity for the purpose of cryptocurrency mining by groups faces imprisonment from 5-8 years. Prosecutor General Habbullo Vohidzoda noted that crypto mining leads to shortages and power outages in some regions of the country. According to him, damage from illegal crypto mining in Tajikistan is $3,520,000. Earlier Deputy Prime Minister Alexander Novak said that illegal cryptocurrency mining may be punishable by criminal responsibility in Russia.

Recent days have often seen headlines about gasoline in the US being cheaper than in Russia. For a while, they became more popular than headlines about our gasoline prices rising again.

Why this shouldn't be given much attention, as well as Trump's comments about America having thousands of years of oil reserves in a respected column.

Writing that the shortage of oil tankers has become so acute, Asian tankers are now sailing empty to load oil instead of being loaded with fuel. Six supertankers bought this year have made trips from Eastern Asia without cargo for loading oil in the Middle East, Africa or America. In comparison, only one such trip was made last year. Overall, according to S&P Global's September calculations, the shadow fleet servicing exports from Venezuela, Iran and Russia totals around 978 ships, which is about 19% of the world tanker fleet. It can be assumed that the seizure of the U.S. tanker Skipper has not only aimed at pressuring Maduro and annoying China but also restraining the increase in the 'shadow fleet.'

The Government of Magadan Oblast has appealed to the Supreme Court of Russia against tariffs for thermal energy. Governor Sergey Nosov said: 'If you buy coal more expensive than on the market, as a result of some popular competition procedures, it does not mean that the quality of your supply service should be borne by an ordinary citizen.' Earlier, the court approved Magadanenergo's lawsuit and ordered to include in the tariff costs for purchasing coal from Kuzbass for Magadan TEC according to the contract concluded with a sole bidder. The regional government appealed against the court decision. If the Supreme Court decides in favor of the region, then competition procedures conducted according to all rules will not be a reason to change the tariff and will fall on the energy companies' money? And what alternative is there, such as limiting energy supply, which would not please anyone?

english: Australia's Northern Territory faces a gas shortage and risks to energy supply. Beetaloo Energy Australia has finalized its investment decision for a shale gas project in the Betalu sub-basin after signing an agreement with the region for gas supplies. While quick increases in production are not possible, the project is still at the exploration stage. Deputy Premier of Northern Territory Gerald May expressed concern that the territory may face shortages and widespread power outages. In 2009, PWC signed a long-term contract with ENI to buy Blacktip gas, but Blacktip's gas production has significantly decreased since early 2021, forcing PWC to purchase gas from alternative sources. Currently, Blacktip's gas extraction is temporarily halted while assessing the damage caused by Cyclone Fin. Local authorities note that until major multinational oil and gas companies export around 80% of Australia-produced gas overseas, Northern Territory will continue facing energy sector problems.

China plans to start commercial operation of its domestically developed small modular reactor APC100 'Linglong-1' with a capacity of 125 MW on Hainan Island in the first half of 2026, announced a spokesperson from China National Nuclear Corporation (CNNC) research division. Small reactors will mainly be used to meet electricity demand in regions with weak power grids, such as islands, said Wang Zhengzhen, president of China Institute of Strategic Studies on Nuclear Industry.

Ukraine attacked the V. Filianovskiy oil field of P "Lukoil" in the Caspian Sea, according to Western media citing Ukrainian authorities. According to sources, the platform was hit at least four times by drones, stopping production on more than 20 producing wells at the field. No official comments have been made. A retaliatory 'letter' will be sent.

subject: inflation, carbon dioxide, methane, oil production, gas production, greenhouse gases, climate change mitigation
english:
Norwegian environmental agency reported record levels of nitrogen oxide in the atmosphere in 2024. Measurements were made at the 'Cepheus' observatory on Svalbard.

The report also recorded record levels of CO and methane.

We should start reducing oil and gas production from Norway. Especially since a green party in Norway achieved the creation of a commission to study Norway's economy leaving behind fossil fuels.

Yes, on this background, the US removed references to oil and gas as factors of global warming, so all responsibility and restrictions should be borne by Europeans, most advanced in this issue. And at the same time developing their dependence on imports.

Lukoil prefers the offer from American bank Xtellus to acquire its foreign assets, Reuters reports. Earlier, the agency wrote that Xtellus proposed a cashless exchange of Lukoil's securities held by US investors in order for them to be returned to Lukoil in exchange for global assets of Russian company. Thus, funds from the sale will not be frozen as required by the U.S. sanctions regime. The questions are: Will the U.S. authorities agree with this option and will other interested parties follow through with asset sales?

The Kyrgyz President Sadyr Japarov completed an official state visit to Islamabad, Pakistan's capital. This visit aims to significantly enhance the economic potential of Kyrgyzstan by using transit goods and services on new markets. Key practical outcomes include agreements that allow Kyrgyzstan access to Pakistani ports Karachi and Gwadar. The sides also agreed to increase bilateral trade tenfold within a few years from current levels to $200 million, indicating serious intentions for intensifying economic ties. This will diversify export routes and reduce dependence on transit through neighboring countries like Kazakhstan and Russia. It could also lower the cost and speed up exports of Kyrgyzstan's goods such as textiles and agricultural products. For Pakistan, this cooperation allows it to strengthen its economic influence in Central Asia and deepen its role in Eurasian logistics, confirming its status as a transit state and intermediary between Central and South Asia.

subject: CASA-1000, infrastructure projects
english: The Kyrgyz President Sadyr Zhaparov's talks in Pakistan included major regional infrastructure projects with regional significance. This includes the 'China-Kyrgyzstan-Uzbekistan' (KKU) railway project and the 'CASA-1000' energy project. The KKU will connect China's rail network through Kyrgyzstan and Uzbekistan to Iran, Turkey, and other European countries. The CASA-1000 aims to transfer excess hydropower from Tajikistan and Kyrgyzstan to Afghanistan and Pakistan via high-voltage power lines over 1,000 km in length. Both projects have strategic importance for Kyrgyzstan as they open a real export channel for electricity generated by existing and new hydroelectric stations.

english: Leading zinc producer and 'copper empire' Kazakhstan is changing hands. Two major construction companies in Kazakhstan, Shakhmurtat Mutaliyev (Integra Construction KZ) and Nurlan Artykbaev (Qazaq Stroy), are currently negotiating the acquisition of controlling stakes in two industrial Kazakh giants representing a strategic sector of Kazakhstan's economy: TO 'Kazinc' and TO 'Corporation Kazmyns'. Preliminary sums for such deals are not disclosed, with parallel tracks of formal negotiations underway. Observers suggest that Mutaliyev and Artykbaev act as trusted parties or temporary holders of assets that will eventually transition under full state control due to their strategic importance to Kazakhstan's economy.

In the last few months, Putin has held five meetings about the front situation. This is the fifth public meeting since the beginning of the war. The press office of the Kremlin reported today that Putin had a meeting about the front situation. Military officials briefed him on almost all fronts, including in Donbas. For two and a half months, this was the fifth public meeting dedicated to the front situation. Before this, President visited the Unified Command Group headquarters twice (26 October and 1 December) and once (20 November). In early October, Putin also had a partly open meeting with military leadership and General Staff. On three of these public meetings, Putin wore military uniform. Usually, Putin did not mention the front situation in public meetings, but now he does it more often. There were few such meetings at the beginning of the war. In March, military officials briefed Putin about the imminent liberation of Kursk region (he was first to wear camouflage), and in April, Chief General Staff Gerasimov reported the end of this operation. In summer 2024, he met with generals twice but did not disclose details or publish photos and videos. No details were provided about Putin's visit to military in Rostov region in autumn 2023 after Wagner mutiny. In the first two years of war, Kremlin used a genre 'Minister of Defense personally reports to the Chief Commander'. But after Shoygu was dismissed in May 2024, this genre is not used anymore. There were only two meetings with General Staff chief Gerasimov this year. The high media activity about front situation has one main target - US President Donald Trump and his administration. Territorial issue is one of the most controversial points at peace talks. Putin demands from Ukrainian President Zelensky to withdraw troops from Donbas, and wants to convince the US that loss of Ukraine in this region is a matter of time. Zelensky does not want to withdraw troops and tries to convince Trump that Putin overestimates Russian army achievements. Today, Zelensky again confirmed that he will not withdraw troops from Donbass but did not rule out a referendum on this issue.

Finished the day with another slight weakening - 518.65 tenge per US dollar and 6.65 tenge per Russian ruble.

english: Freedom Holding Corp. CEO Timur Turlov discusses the future ecosystem of digital technologies that accompany people in learning, work, investments, and daily actions. The company has seen explosive growth with revenue exceeding $1 billion for the first quarter of 2026. Freedom SuperApp now has over 4 million users and is a main 'entry' into the ecosystem and source of traffic and clients for the bank. Next step: integrate LLM models to turn the app into a personal financial advisor and integrate more government services (GovTech 2.0) + gamification and its own loyalty currency. Freedom builds Tier IV data center Akashi with 100 MW and network Freedom Cloud from seven centers across the country, develops telecom and 5G, purchases AI capabilities on NVIDIA chips and partnerships with global players. This is part of a strategy to turn Kazakhstan into an IT and AI hub in Central Asia according to President's message. ESG and social investments: through the 'Freedom Shapakat' fund, the company invests tens of billions tenge in social projects: 27.8 billion for ESG in 2025, including 6.2 billion on sports (chess, QJ League), infrastructure cities (Naberezhna in Konayev, monuments), education, Aral ecology and green energy. Turlov sees the ecosystem not as a set of services but as a 'digital layer' of life: finances, communication, education, health, media and lifestyle as one unified environment helping to grow and make informed decisions. AI should become a new interface - personal autonomous agent removing routine and enhancing human capital, while the ecosystem complements rather than replaces state policy.

Deputies want to dismantle the insurance market. Next week, in the Majilis, hearings will begin on a law project that could destabilize the insurance market. The Insurance Law Amendments Project for Passenger Vehicle Owners (VTS) was initiated by Majilis Deputy Elnur Beysembaev of the Amanat Party. Deputies want to double the compensation limits for mandatory auto insurance. However, they do not want to raise insurance premiums they justify their position by saying that insurance companies already earn enough money. The deputies believe that insurance companies are making a profit from the simple car owner's money. Strange logic on the part of the deputies because in reality, compulsory insurance for vehicle owners is a deeply unprofitable type of insurance. The growth of compensation claims for mandatory insurance for vehicle owners has significantly exceeded premium growth over the past 5 years (from 46% to 87%) and even during the first seven months of this year it reached 96%, which is also related to a significant increase in traffic accidents (fatal accident rate increased more than twice). If we do not take into account the transport of legal entities and transit transportation, then the profitability coefficient fluctuates between 108-119%. In reality, what are deputies proposing? Doubling compensation limits without raising premiums. That is, doubling insurance companies' losses. Where's the logic? Or does the plan of the elected representatives include bankrupting insurance companies? To force insurers to abandon VTS licenses for compulsory insurance? If so, this would be a proposal to abolish mandatory auto insurance.

Explained on Business FM about the ENPF thresholds. First, they should have been raised long ago, secondly, the current increase isn't very strong - it's only around a 10% rise. However, throughout history, there remains one question: the formula for the thresholds, which supposedly takes into account the minimum wage, raises questions. Last year, the thresholds did not rise.

english: Starting from January 1, 2026, all trade and service companies in Uzbekistan will implement a unified QR code for accepting electronic payments. From July 1st, the absence of this QR code will be considered as a violation of trading rules.

From July, the tax base for real estate and building materials in Uzbekistan will be calculated based on their market value. Foreign companies selling goods or services to Uzbeks online must register with tax authorities otherwise their activities in the country will be restricted. In July, former Tax Committee head Sherzod Kudbyev said there were mass cases of understating prices when selling real estate in Uzbekistan: 2000 notarized deals concluded at a price below 1 million soum per square meter, and 9300 deals from 1 to 3 million soums. subject: inflation, wages, budget, deficit
english: The vice premier Balayeva held a meeting to prepare for the education system. They discussed the shortage of teaching staff. Teachers are indeed lacking. The material issue plays a large role. Several years ago, the government boasted how much they raised teachers' salaries. Now in the country there is high inflation, which even according to official data is double-digit, and in reality - we all feel how it is. On profitable markets, private companies raise wages to retain valuable staff. Private schools can increase tuition fees to index salary increases for employees. However, the government, due to a huge budget deficit, cannot adjust salaries for hundreds of thousands of teachers even at the level of official inflation. In the next 3-4 years, an increase will happen only during parliamentary and then presidential electoral campaigns - if the government manages to stabilize the budget. Until then, purchasing power of wages will fall - which will determine the dynamics of personnel. As usual, there is a shortage of key areas. 'If we lack subject experts, for example, mathematicians it means that grants should be provided,' Balayeva notes. If talking specifically about mathematicians, it's not only about a staff shortage but also about the structure of existing teaching staff. I fear to offend feminists, but gender imbalance in teaching exact sciences does not positively affect the quality of teaching. There would be more men among mathematicians and physicists if there were fewer women. However, these men get married and need to feed their families. Perhaps it is necessary to introduce additional incentives for attracting men into the profession? For partial correction of the imbalance. In general, Kazakhstan has somewhat luck that an era of artificial intelligence begins. Hundreds of professionals can develop complex programs capable of more or less accurately targeting different groups of children in terms of speed and quality of learning activity. Launched a neural network, passed testing, answered several questions - and it understood what exactly you lack, developed a special program for you personally. Plus - recommendations for teachers (and if needed - tutors). If not for the prospect of AI implementation, it would be difficult to expect positive changes in the current dynamics of average quality teaching staff compared to time requirements.

The president of Iran, Peshkejian, visited Astana. The Iranian direction is interesting for Kazakhstan from a logistics point of view - the railway to the south to the Gulf and possibly even west to Turkey. Also, supplies of goods in demand in Iran, including agricultural products.

subject: debt, deficit, employment, wages, industrial production, trade, exports, imports, investment, FDI
english: If spreading false information by the media directly or indirectly but clearly and deliberately aimed at large-scale negative consequences of political, social, economic destabilization capable of plunging a country into crisis, then criminal cases can be filed strictly in accordance with the law. If harmful scenarios are not visible, then problems can be solved through ordinary court lawsuits. Did journalists lie? An open trial lawsuit - if the plaintiff is right, removal, refutation, compensation for proven damage. Several successful cases against perpetrators who lied under the guise of journalist's credentials - this will immediately set the necessary state accents. However, filing criminal cases for each suspected '2+2=5' when false information can easily be refuted in public space does not seem to be the most optimal mechanism for solving problems.

Kazakhstan continues to experiment and reflect in search of the most optimal designs for its political system. In 2022, they returned single-seat constituencies on elections to the Majilis. In 2025, they decided to return to a pure proportional system. In 2023, they started directly electing district mayors. In 2025, civic figures and deputies already propose revising the mechanism, making elections indirect - through local councils. The point is: some 'outsiders' irritate with 'incompetence', 'uncontrollability', 'instability', and 'populism'. And responsible party comrades will always support, advise, and punish. So the focus again shifts to parties.

About the head of KZTC, Aldybergenov, and his speech at a briefing in the government. I often say that moving mountains with words is one thing, but understanding technical industries is another. We, humanists, are ready to deliver a brilliant speech about the country's fate at any moment. I don't think so, but I know for sure that engineers find it much harder. If you look at Aldybergenov's biography - 35 years strictly in logistics and production sectors. I believe the specificity of work implies more male conversation with less talkative engineers than long speeches by all sorts of orators. Different people have different qualities. Some may stumble under external pressures like fatigue, stress, concentration on other issues. This disqualifies a purely political manager but is perfectly acceptable for an engineer. What concerns me most are the current affairs at KZTC. Is there ongoing work to reduce long-term debt load? Are transport links with neighbors developing? How fairly do imports and exports distribute capacities in the interests of national economy. Is there modernization of fleet. In particular: how well goods go to Aktau port. Do we have enough throughput (and earn) on transit from China to Europe. Is it comfortable for exporters to export products. These questions interest me first, not that a sectoral manager suddenly stumbled over some overloaded data sheet.

subject: debt, exports, imports, investment, budget, deficit

english: Placement for up to 11,000 EV charging stations in 53 regions of Russia will be determined by an AI system developed domestically. The AI analyzes anonymized city data, transportation activity and user behavior to identify areas with the highest demand for electric vehicle charging. This approach will help optimally distribute the stations and increase their efficiency. The network of charging stations planned by Rosatom in partnership with Yandex aims to develop by 2030, creating infrastructure for growth in electric vehicles and supporting the transition to clean transport.

In Russia, there is a proposal to introduce special fuel cards for multi-child families. The government and oil companies are currently considering discounts or free fuel limits, as well as the risks of abusing the benefits. The initiative was launched in October after a children's ombudsman's request and Alexander Novak's instructions. Oil companies generally support the approach but note administrative difficulties with targeted fuel cards and uncertainty about compensating for provided discounts. There are almost 2.9 million multi-child families in Russia. The Ministry of Energy is ready to consider the format of preferential fuel cards, noting that there are already general loyalty programs at gas stations. If approved, businesses will need to expand their staff and adjust budgets.

english: Frontline roads in terrible condition, despite being the only alternative for Ukrainian troops to avoid enemy FPV-drones attacks. A vivid example is the road from Izium-Slavyansk-Kramatorsk which has been under continuous Russian FPV-drone attacks for several months. Troops continue using it because an alternate route through Barysvino is in terrible condition: potholes up to knee height, speed limit 20-30 km/h, suspension breaks, and transporting wounded almost impossible. Barysvino should have been repaired 'yesterday' as troops are forced to choose between risking their lives and destroying equipment. This affects their safety and normal logistics. The Constitutional Court of Kyrgyz Republic refused to consider the question of returning capital punishment. The court reminded that human rights and freedoms are the highest value, and the system of their guarantees forms the foundation of the constitutional order and limits permissible changes to the Constitution. Any amendments in this area should take into account the systemic nature of rights, possible consequences for the entire model of their protection, and the non-diminution (non-regress) of the level of guarantees, as stability and consistency in protecting human rights and dignity is a key constitutional priority.

There is no official confirmation of these claims. The Service for the Execution of Sentences in Kyrgyz Republic commented on Sultanbaev's sister's statement: 'Conditions of Temirkan Sultanbaev's detention comply with the law. Information about his placement in a cell with someone who has tuberculosis is not confirmed. In pre-trial detention-1, no one is held with diseases - there is a special institution No 31. english: Discount Urals to Brent exceeded $20 per barrel. Average price of Urals crude oil decreased from $52.1 to $41.1 per barrel in October-November 2025 according to Argus data. This is the highest average discount since April 2023, when it was $24.9 per barrel due to EU sanctions. November prices were the lowest since February 2022. The sharp increase in the discount is directly related to stricter sanctions against two major Russian oil companies. In 2026, the discount will decrease, especially with a likely easing of sanctions, but in Q1 2026, the Ministry of Finance may record a multi-year low for oil and gas revenues due to lower prices lagging their impact on NDD (Non-Deductible Deduction) and NDPI (Non-Deductible Petroleum Income).

The Constitutional Court of Kyrgyzstan rejected the president's request to reinstate capital punishment. The court analyzed a petition from the President asking for constitutional amendments allowing for the reinstatement of death penalty for rape and murder, including sexual violence. After reviewing the document, the court declared that initiatives contradict constitutional principles and international obligations of the country, so the project cannot be put on referendum. Emphasis was made on international legal norms. The state is a party to the Second Optional Protocol to the International Covenant on Civil and Political Rights, which prohibits any form of death penalty and does not allow for its withdrawal.

Indian medicines continue to be smuggled into Uzbekistan. Authorities seized a shipment of uncertified drugs worth 1.6 billion soums in Tashkent. The owner was preparing the goods for sale and was arrested, with an investigation opened.

The Kazakh authorities have issued an arrest warrant for the husband and mother-in-law of a murdered Kazakhstan woman in Germany. The body of former Kazakh judge Aigul Saylybaeva was found near Bensheim, Germany in June 2024. Lawyer Zhanna Urazbakhova reported to the press facts indicating torture, pregnancy of the victim, and possible involvement of several people. An arrest warrant has been issued for the husband (Alexander Don) and mother-in-law (Natalia Doncova). The case was registered on December 9, 2025 in the Jetyussky region.

A lawmaker from Kazakhstan's National Party raised the issue of 'foreign agents' in parliament. He mentioned that USAID had provided over $150 million in grants to Kazakhstan over ten years, and that the total annual 'foreign agent budget' is around $60 million. The speaker demanded transparency about donors, funding amounts, project goals, and audit reports.

China demanded that the Taliban investigate the deaths of its citizens in Tajikistan. UN representative Fu Kun urged the government of the Taliban to conduct a 'serious investigation' into the death of Chinese citizens in Tajikistan as a result of attacks carried out from Afghan territory. At the Security Council meeting on Afghanistan, he condemned the killing of Chinese citizens committed during attacks from Afghan territory. The diplomat called for both the Taliban and Tajikistan to strengthen border control.

Asel Zhanasova has been appointed Deputy Head of the President's Administration. The head of state relieved her from her previous position as a counselor. Zhanasova began her career in 2010 at ENRC Kazakhstan, then led the holding 'Zerde', worked on digital technologies at MFAA, and was Vice Minister for Trade and Integration. In 2022 she became Chairman of the Board of KAZPOST, and in 2025 counselor to the President of Kazakhstan. Now Zhanasova is moving to a new position in the Presidential Administration.

english: The name of the businessman became widely discussed after Bloomberg reported his potential interest in Kazakhmys. His biography is almost unknown. He earned his fortune through construction, owning Qazaq Stroy since 2003 and building over 2 million square meters of housing. The group includes 77 companies with revenue exceeding 300 billion tenge. Exclusive Qurylys also belongs to him; both companies decided to merge in 2023. In recent years, the businessman expanded his assets beyond construction. He created Qazaq Kalium Ltd., planning to launch a potassium plant in ZAO, and later Gas Solutions Ltd. for gas extraction.

Ukraine may join the EU in 2027. Such a point is being discussed in the US. Besides Ukraine's entry, international guarantees of security, a demilitarized zone along the front line, and the withdrawal of Russian troops from Zaporozhye Nuclear Power Plant are also being discussed. The plan consists of three parts: conditions for peace, security guarantees, and economic assistance. Kyiv insists that it will not legally refuse its territories. Zelensky already stated that he does not have such a right. One of the compromise variants 'Korean model' is when war stops but the dispute over territories remains unresolved.

Shodiyev and his daughter Munisa lost an appeal in a dispute with Ibragimov over Eurasian Financial Company. The court upheld the previous decision, which ordered Eurasian Bank to implement decisions of its board from June 2 and July 30, 2025: approve financial statements for 2024 and conduct personnel appointments in the board of Eurasian Bank. Chairman of the board is Ibragimov. The updated board includes Ibragimov, Vitaly Repay, Arman Nurushev, Erlan Musin, and Zhantoka Bekenov. Inessa Kim's powers are terminated, and Zhantoka Bekenov is appointed as Director executive body of Eurasian Financial Company.

An Italian company, which lost a court case in Russia, continues to develop projects in Kazakhstan worth $10 billion. Tecnimont S.p.A., part of the Maire group, stated that their projects in Kazakhstan continue without interruptions despite the Russian court decision. The company won against 'EuroChem Severo-Zapad-2' and now has to pay over 171 billion rubles (about 2 billion euros). They emphasized that decisions from Russian courts do not apply outside Russia under the New York Convention of 1958, so they don't affect contracts in Kazakhstan. The company is involved in two major projects worth more than $10 billion - a polyethylene plant for 'Sileno' in Atyrau region and a gas separation complex on the Tengiz field for KazMunayGas.

Export of Kazakhstan's oil is at risk due to repairs on the KTK terminal. With only one operational offshore berth, two others are either damaged by drones or under planned maintenance. This has led to oil stockpiling on storage facilities. If they overflow, Kazakhstan will be forced to reduce production. The Ministry of Energy and KTK have not yet commented.
