english: The Pentagon has chosen Google's AI model Gemini for use by three million military and civilian employees. The decision was made as part of the launch of GenAI.mil, which will implement generative AI in all branches of the US Department of Defense. The system will analyze video and images to give an advantage on 'the digital battlefield'. The $200 million contract with Google is for OpenAI, xAI, and Anthropic. 'We will continue to actively deploy the best technologies in the world to make our armed forces more capable than ever before,' said Secretary of War Pete Hegset.

On the railway section Muynty Shyganak, four people died in a train accident during planned rail replacement work. The incident occurred when a freight train suddenly braked while workers were on the tracks at Sarystagank station. A special commission was formed to investigate the cause of the accident.

In Pavlodar, schoolchildren tried to cut the tongue of a seven-year-old child. The mother published a video message on Telegram channel Halyqstan. She says that the attackers were around ten years old and hit him in his body and head. Then they used scissors and injured his tongue. The Pavlodar woman asks for help from possible witnesses and owners of cars with cameras.

A seven-year-old boy claimed that he was attacked by schoolchildren and had his tongue cut with scissors. The police interviewed neighbors and reviewed footage from surveillance cameras, concluding there was no attack. After seeing blood, the child pretended to be injured to attract attention from his father. He will be seen on a commission for juvenile affairs after being discharged from the hospital.

Four people died under a freight train in Karaganda region. The tragedy occurred on the SheshenkaKarajangal section of the railway line at Saryszagan station, which was conducting planned rail replacement work. Despite emergency braking by the driver, the accident could not be prevented. Four workers received fatal injuries. A special commission will investigate the incident. 'The commission has already arrived at the scene for investigation. Kazakhstan Temir Zholy Company expresses deep condolences to the families of the deceased.'

Students in the first grades of schools in Astana are again sent to remote work due to weather conditions. 'Due to worsening weather conditions on December 11, 2025, students from the first shift will transition to a remote learning format,' the city's education administration reported. On most parts of the country on December 11, KazHydromet predicts snow, increased wind, fog, and blizzard in western, southern, and eastern regions. A storm warning has been declared in most regions.

Prisoners who injured themselves to get benefits were given new sentences. In the Turkestan region, a court punished six prisoners for mass disobedience of prison administration. The convicted offenders, serving sentences for serious and especially serious crimes in strict regime colony No. 55, demanded illegal benefits by mutual agreement. Among their demands were watching TV at night, free outdoor time, self-preparation of food, refusal from the established clothing form and other prohibited by law concessions. To achieve their conditions, they deliberately inflicted bodily injuries on themselves. The court found them guilty and sentenced each to a term of imprisonment ranging from 5 to 10 years with continued serving in more strict conditions.
In Almaty, a storm warning is issued for December 11. The city will experience severe weather conditions - strong cold and ice. This was announced by the Emergency Committee of Almaty.

A vandal who was grilling meat on the Eternal Flame was arrested in Riddar. The police detained a local man, 31 years old, after checking nearby neighborhoods and reviewing surveillance footage. He was charged with desecrating buildings, public places, etc., and sentenced to administrative detention for five days.

15 passengers on a bus barely escaped freezing temperatures in Kazakhstan's Karaganda region. The incident occurred at km 1007 of the republic's highway from Karaganda to Shidert. The Van Hool bus, heading towards Russia, stopped due to frozen diesel fuel. Temperatures dropped to -25C. Police evacuated passengers to a warming point in the village of Mayozek. No threats to their lives or health remain.

Father of Biysembeu gave testimony in court over $1 million embezzlement. Four people died under a train in Karaganda region. Elementary school students were sent home again due to weather. Prisoners who hurt themselves for benefits received new sentences in Turkestan. 15 bus passengers almost froze on the Kaigran-Kashyrt road. @kursivm #kursiv_digest

US Customs and Border Protection suggested tightening rules for visa-free entry. Passengers from 42 countries, including the UK, France, Germany, and South Korea, may be required to provide social media account data from the last five years, email addresses from ten years ago, and detailed information about family members. Currently, visa application is done through ESTA system: just fill in contact details and pay $40, valid for two years. Previously, in 2025, State Department required some visa applicants to make their social media public.

Ariana Sobolenko expressed opposition to the participation of transwomen in women's tennis. As quoted by Piers Morgan, she considers it unfair for biologically male athletes to compete against female competitors who have worked hard throughout their lives to reach their level. She will play a mixed doubles exhibition match with Niko Kirios on December 28th in Dubai.

The Constitutional Court rejected Kyrgyzstan's president's initiative to reinstate the death penalty. The court emphasized that human rights are a fundamental value of the state and cannot be weakened. They noted that abolishing the death penalty has both legal and moral significance, and any attempts to reverse these guarantees are unacceptable. The court also reminded that Kyrgyzstan must fulfill international agreements and cannot rely on internal norms to reject these obligations.

The government of Kazakhstan announced that the returned assets worth 15 billion tenge will be used for water supply in the Jambyl region. The government plans to build 12 water facilities, four of which are already completed in villages such as Kyzylushar, Zhanaotkel, Zhuma and Karoy, providing clean water. Eight more facilities are expected to be finished by the end of the year in Moyunsumsky, Sarysusky and Kordaysky districts. Water access is almost fully provided in the region: 98% in cities and 99.3% in villages. The country's budget allocated over 240 billion tenge for water supply by 2025.

subject: wages, employment, exports, imports
english: A summary of salaries and job activity in Kazakhstan. Employers listed about 101,000 vacancies (down 23%), while job seekers submitted around 101,000 resumes (down 11%). The message also mentions high salaries for pilots and IT managers.

subject: inflation,GDP
english: @kursivm #kursiv_finance

subject: budget, debt, deficit, reserves, trade, exports, imports, investment, FDI
english: Audit found that Kazakh citizens artificially inflated their incomes and were listed in dozens of companies to receive higher benefits. In one example, 169 people worked in more than 16 organizations simultaneously. The audit also showed that the Fund of Social Security extracted unnecessary assets, leading to inefficient spending of 216 billion tenge. Additionally, 96 billion tenge was lost due to lack of restrictions on social benefits and weak data exchange with tax authorities.

The President of Iran arrived on an official visit to Astana. The Head of Kazakhstan, Kassym-Jomart Tokayev, personally greeted Mohammad Bagher Pesetski. They will hold talks on trade, transport, logistics and humanitarian projects.

original:
Home Credit Bank 

 ForteBank . . 

 20 . , ForteBank Kassa Nova .

 . Home Credit Bank. , , Home Credit Bank. 

@kursivm #kursiv_news
english: Home Credit Bank will be led by former Alliance Bank head Sholpan Nurymbet. She will take office after approval of AARRFR. Nurymbet has over 20 years of banking experience, holding senior positions in banks that later became part of ForteBank - Kassa Nova Bank and Alliance Bank. The appointment of Sholpan Nurymbet strengthens the bank's team during integration. Home Credit Bank thanks Kirill for his professionalism and contribution to developing Home Credit Bank. His leadership helped stabilize operations and prepare the bank for the next transformation phase.

Kazakhstan will increase oil exports to China via other routes after attacks on the Kazakhstan-China pipeline. Supplies in December increased by 72,000 tons through the Baku-Tbilisi-Ceyhan route (58,000 tons) and by 232,000 tons through the Aktobe-Samara route. To ensure logistics flexibility, KazTransOil will allow oil producers to temporarily store oil in a reserve park, which will help smooth out shipment schedules and maintain stable flow.

Unannounced inspections of schools and kindergartens will start in Kazakhstan. From February 1, 2026, a new system of state control will be implemented. Changes are possible due to amendments to the Law on Children's Rights, which strengthen safety and quality service requirements. Chairman of the Committee for the Protection of Childrens Rights Nasymzhana Ospanova noted that unannounced inspections will allow faster reaction to signals of violations and timely action.

Papa John's closes in Kazakhstan and Kyrgyzstan. Owner Danyar Monolbaev says the business became unprofitable: revenue was falling, costs were rising, debts were accumulating. He redirected remaining funds to key payments - salaries, taxes, rent, and part of the debt. Most employees in Kazakhstan found new jobs at other companies. Papa John's entered the Kazakh market in 2017 and opened 15 pizza parlors.

original:
, , . 

 Kazakhmys Copper K.C.C B.V. KCC Copper Limited, 2025 . .

 Kazakhmys Holding Limited, - .

 , . , .

@kursivm #kursiv_news
english: Kazakhmys, a mining corporation owned by Vladimir Kim and Eduard Oganov that plans to sell its assets, has moved from the Netherlands to Astana. The parent company Kazakhmys Copper changed its shareholders; instead of K.C.C B.V., it is now registered as KCC Copper Limited in Astana since November 2025. The new entity was created under MFA jurisdiction and controlled by Kazakhmys Holding Limited, which still belongs to Kim and Oganov. Experts suggest that restructuring the structure may be part of preparations for the sale of assets. Economist Arman Batayev previously noted that the creation of a separate holding before the potential deal could indicate future structuring through MFA.

How Akimat of Almaty is fighting with overcrowded buses? They just monitor the situation. Residents of the city every day complain about filled buses, sometimes you can't even get in. '' contacted Akimat to find out how they solve this problem. Here's what we were told: According to Akimat data, intervals between buses are violated due to traffic jams and some drivers skipping stops. In Akimat, for fighting with this, they conduct monitoring of the population complaints and buses. If the authorities detect a violation, then bus driver should lose part of subsidies. On the question about how in overcrowded buses people's safety is ensured not answered by Akimat. But there also added that on 48 routes will start additional buses until the end of the year.

Netflix released the trailer for the second season of Avatar: The Legend of Aang. Streaming platform published video on YouTube channel, which has already gathered over a million views. In the second season, Aang, Katara and Sokka will leave Water Tribe and embark on a journey where main hero starts mastering Earth's magic. For the first time in the franchise, Tohru appears - one of the most popular characters. Fans also noted how much Avatar actor has changed. Premiere of the second season is expected in 2026.

The family of deceased Kazakhstan minister's son, Kalandar Biyshimbayev, donated 1.5 million tenge to Satalyn Nukanova for the funeral. The case against Bekzat Kemelov, suspected in a $1 million fraud, is ongoing in Astana. Biyshimbayev's father, Valikhan Biyshimbayev, said Kemelov personally gave 1.5 million tenge to Satalyn Nukanova's family for the funeral arrangements. He emphasized that this was an ordinary gathering without any discussion of 'questions.'

A Chinese company wants to modernize Kazakhstan's energy facilities. This was announced after meetings between representatives of the Ministry of Foreign Affairs, Kazakh Invest, and Zhongyoung Power's leadership. The company is considering participating in a national project for energy modernization and is willing to invest through PPP or models with repayment via tariffs. It also stated its readiness to use Kazakhstan-made equipment. Parties discussed updating substations, replacing old equipment, and building new transformer capacities. Kazakhstan proposed localizing part of the production within the country.

Kazakhstan lost 480,000 tons of oil due to attacks on the KTK. Minister of Energy Eralan Akkenzhanov said that plans for 2025 will be fulfilled, while plans for 2026 are uncertain but likely lower than this year.

USA seized a Venezuelan tanker off its shores. Trump called it 'the largest tanker in history.' After this news, Brent crude price rose to $62.21 and WTI to $58.46. This is the first tanker seizure with Venezuelan oil since 2019.

Iran handed Kazakhstan copies of 27 valuable ancient manuscripts. President Kassym-Jomart Tokayev mentioned at talks with Iran's Masoud Peshkevan in Aqtau that the documents contain unique information about the Kazakh Khanate: its relations with neighboring states, political situation in Turkestan, and descriptions of coal, copper, iron, and jade mines. Tokayev emphasized that Kazakhstan and Iran actively develop cultural-humane cooperation. Already started joint study of Al-Farabi's heritage, and in the country plans to build a separate historical-cultural complex dedicated to this great thinker.

China urged the Taliban to investigate deaths of its citizens on the Tajikistan border. China demanded that active groups like ISIL, Eastern Turkestan Islamic Movement, and Pakistan's TTP be eliminated. Beijing also asked Dushanbe and the Taliban to strengthen control at the border, offering cooperation for stability.

subject: exports, imports
english: @kursivm #kursiv_news

NASA lost contact with a satellite that had been orbiting Mars for 10 years. The Maven, launched in 2013 and entering orbit in 2014, was supposed to study the upper layers of Mars' atmosphere and how they are affected by the Sun. These data help understand why Mars lost most of its atmosphere, how its climate changed, and whether there could have been liquid water on the planet.

Akim of Shymkent commented on the statement that he was allegedly involved in the attack on his deputy Ruslan Berdenov. The defendant Erenar Jeymabay said that if he accused the akim Habit Szydykbayev of a murder-for-hire, Berdenov would forgive him. Journalists asked the akim what he thinks about this. He replied: 'The press service showed rumors that I was removed because my arrival caused the city to transform. This is not so. Even after a month from his appointment he only got involved in matters. What happened next, you know yourself. Each person has the right to think as they see fit. The idea that I have anything to do with this is their personal assumptions. How can I be related to this? People say whatever they need to justify themselves correctly. The court made a decision the situation was resolved, and I think there's no need to repeatedly raise this issue.'

A train carrying 52 people who were poisoned with gas has not been operated by KZTJ (Kazakhstani State Transport Joint-Stock Company) but by a private company. At Almaty-2 station, besides adults, 10 children were also affected - two of them were sent to the intensive care unit. 'The train involved in the poisoning does not belong to AO Passenger Transport and is owned by a private transport company. The cars were provided to a film studio for shooting purposes', reported KZTJ.

Aur became the first Kazakh film with a rating of 21+, which collected over 1 billion tenge in theaters. The creators thanked the audience and noted that such results were possible only due to audience support. According to distributor estimates, the movie missed out on between 600 to 800 million tenge due to its age rating. They also added that this is now the last week of showing.

Also in the akimat, 'Cursive' was told why they are not planning to change the subsidy system. Currently, subsidies work by mileage method - that is, the akimat pays for the actual bus travel distance. They do not plan to abandon this scheme. They explain that the number of public transport trips increases every year and if subsidies were strictly paid based on the number of passengers transported, the total amount could exceed the budget. At the same time, the costs of transportation companies for maintaining routes remain within planned limits. Therefore, the mileage method, as explained by the akimat, allows covering real company losses and is considered optimal. We also asked if there would be alternative payment methods for travel. According to the akimat, now cooperation with Kaspi QR and other companies is being considered.

Akm Shymkent Gazimbekov announced that in 2025, the city will allocate 99 million tenge for festive decoration. He said some decorations are reused but additional work is needed in some locations, leading to higher costs. 'We save everywhere. All materials from last year are stored in district warehouses and will be used again. This year, I plan to set up a real Christmas tree,' he said at the briefing in SCK. Journalists reminded that in 2024, festive decoration cost 80 million tenge. He explained the increase in costs due to necessary renovations in some locations.

Trump's $1 million golden citizenship card for the US has been activated. Direct path to citizenship for qualified and verified candidates. Great news! American great companies can finally keep their valuable employees.

Taxi in Temirtau is offering free rides and checking Kazakh language knowledge. The project 'TAKSIDEGI QUIZ' started on December 3rd, created by the city Resource Language Center. The idea is to popularize the Kazakh language among residents of different ethnic groups and help people overcome the language barrier. This was reported in the Akimats of Karaganda Oblast. During the ride, passengers are asked questions in Kazakh. For correct answers, they receive commemorative gifts. What happens if the answer is incorrect this was not specified by the center. The taxi operates daily from 17:00 to 19:00. 'During these hours there is a shortage of taxis: people go home, pick up children, take them for classes. Therefore, we chose peak hours', explained the center.

subject: budget, debt, exports, imports, investment, FDI
english: Bank of Development Kazakhstan is returning early to the National Fund 23.5 billion tenge from a total of 50 billion received in 2014. The bank will return almost half of these funds by December this year. These funds were used to finance 13 industrial projects, including LTE networks and gasification, modernization of KazAztat, construction of Turgusun hydroelectric power plant, expansion of Aktas port.

Kasym-Jomart Tokayev and Masud Peshkovian participated in the Kazakhstan-Iran business forum. Kazakhstan and Iran agreed to expand trade and cooperation. Plans include increasing bilateral trade turnover to $2 billion. The focus is on logistics: a joint terminal at Shahid Rajabi port, strengthening ties between Aktau and Kuryk with Iranian ports, and transiting through Kazakh-Turkmen-Iranian route by 2030 could double. In the agricultural sector, Iran's Solico Group will build a dairy plant for 200 thousand tons of production per year and start producing infant formula. Kazakhstan bets on digitalization. Tokayev invited Iranian business to cooperate in technology and crypto-industry. Tokayev proposed a joint state program for saving the Caspian Sea and holding new summits.

Strong snowstorms in Kazakhstan have slowed down some trains. On several railway sections, speed has been reduced and additional safety measures have been implemented by the KZ Railway. Visibility at Dostyk station was practically zero due to strong winds of up to 30 m/s and heavy snowfall. Maintenance work had to be suspended, and 114 railway workers were involved in clearing tracks, including 67 working overnight. Currently, 25 employees are still clearing crossings from snow. Restrictions also apply on the Baskol-Dostyk section, where freight transport is affected. On lines Shu-Shyganak and Shokpar-Alaygyr, trains move slower for safety reasons. According to weather forecasts, strong winds and heavy snow will continue in December across many regions of the country. The border crossing Altyngol-Horgos operates normally.

subject: exports, imports, investment, FDI
english: @kursivm #kursiv_news

In Astana, a tandyrna (traditional oven) collapsed and burned. A one-story addition to a two-story building caught fire on M. Zhumabeva street in Almaty. Gas-air mixture exploded before firefighters arrived, causing part of the tandyrna to collapse. Firefighters quickly removed five gas cylinders and prevented the fire from spreading to the main building. The blaze was quickly extinguished. Four workers were taken to the hospital with burns. Their condition is being assessed.

A one-month ban on importing chicken eggs has been implemented in Kazakhstan. The Ministry of Agriculture issued a decree that took effect on December 11 and lasts for one month. It applies to all types of transportation. This means you cannot import eggs from any countries, including those within the Eurasian Economic Union or third-party countries. However, there are exceptions: the ban does not apply to transiting eggs through Kazakhstan's territory if they are heading to another country; nor does it affect egg movement between countries in the EAEU via Kazakhstan. The Ministry of Agriculture explained that this temporary ban was implemented to support Kazakhstani egg producers and protect the domestic market. The goal is to allow local farms to operate stably and supply the country with products.

President of Kazakhstan Kassym-Jomart Tokayev arrived in Ashgabat for the forum on World and Trust. At the airport, he was met by Chairman of the Halk Maslakhat of Turkmenistan Gurbanguly Berdimuhamedov. 'The agenda we were offered is more than relevant in today's unstable, unpredictable world, especially in the context of the 80th anniversary of the creation of the United Nations,' Tokayev said. Berdimuhamedov thanked the high guest for participating in the forum and highlighted the significance of bilateral cooperation in economy and cultural-humane sphere. 'I would like to thank you for your personal contribution to strengthening relations between Turkmenistan and Kazakhstan. On behalf of our fraternal Kazakh people, I convey best wishes.'

Kazakhstan's President Kassym-Jomart Tokayev met with Turkmenistan's President Serdar Berdymukhammedov. During the meeting, leaders discussed cooperation prospects in trade, logistics, energy and other areas where the countries have established close ties and are ready to move forward further. Turkmenistan's president warmly welcomed his colleague.

In Kostanay region, Deputy Director of Oblzdrav E. Dospanov was arrested for abuse of official duties. The Department of KNB in Kostanay region reported the arrest of Dospanov, deputy head of Oblzdrav. Other details are not disclosed due to Article 201 of the Criminal Procedure Code of Kazakhstan.

The idea of reintroducing the death penalty was dismissed by constitutional court judges who were instructed by Kyrgyz President Japarov to form a conclusion. The Constitutional Court repeated arguments made at the UN. It seems that the administration's interpretation of legal risks is too careless, as it claimed 'no risks' in the corresponding field of legal risks in the explanatory note to the law project.

Could Kyrgyzstan break its system and hold a referendum anyway. But the likely scenario is negligible. Risks of being thrown off the civilized international community and creating a precedent for exiting signed agreements in Central Asia - huge. Therefore, Kyrgyz President Sadyr Japarov preferred diplomatically to omit the initiated process of reviewing the relevant article of the Constitution of the Republic on the day when the UN Universal Declaration of Human Rights was adopted. On that same day, he met with the Ombudsman of Kyrgyzstan for human rights, Jamila Djamanbaeva. He also congratulated the people on the Day of Protection of Rights and again - no mention of returning the death penalty or refusing possible changes. The people were stirred, public discussions were held, but after criticism from those who 'support' - they fell silent, leaving a sense of wonder: 'What was that?'

Google and Apple sent messages to their users about possible cyberattacks. The messages were sent worldwide by Google, and by more than 150 countries including Kazakhstan, Uzbekistan, Pakistan, Saudi Arabia, Angola, Egypt, Tajikistan. There was no selectivity in the warnings or potential attacks - they did not have any geographical targeting.

The route has been restructured. Kyrgyzstan is trying to gain access to Pakistani ports. In order to enter the global market, Kyrgyz President Sadyr Japarov discussed with Pakistan's Prime Minister Shahbaz Sharif using Karachi and Gwadar ports. The goal is to increase bilateral trade by 10 times. Kyrgyzstan hopes for a long-term access to new markets of supply. In exchange, infrastructure construction through Tajikistan will be accelerated, which will allow supplying Pakistan with 'summer surpluses' electricity in the framework of the CASA-1000 project. However, do not forget about Pakistan's interests in the region especially considering its ties with Britain and cooperation with OIC. Kyrgyzstan's and Tajikistan's investments in exporting electricity to Islamabad are not ready to be considered separately from the exploitation of Kyrgyz mining sites. Considering the permanent conflict between Afghanistan and Pakistan, as well as several transit countries on the way to Pakistani ports, building a new route for Kyrgyzstan will be costly and difficult. Its success will depend on many factors over which in Bishkek they have no control.

A year on Kyrgyzstan's ambassador to the US has ended with Moldogazyev losing his position. 'Successes' look especially pale against active communication with neighboring Uzbekistan and Kazakhstan. Building relationships with a country that first in its National Strategy moved Russia from enemy to partner will be former Mongolian envoy Aidarali Atykbay.

Government officials in Kyrgyzstan now seem to be afraid of spending extra som and try to allocate 'budget funds not provided, work is being carried out with the support of partners'. Even if the expenditures are justified - for example, New Year's. Shaking happens either from fear of possible accusations of corruption or excessive unnecessary spending, or a feeling that they will have to report again about glowing 24/7 Christmas lights in times of budget deficit, preventing sleep. But this post will be read in high offices and we will prevent the cancellation of the Bishkek New Year illumination.

Kyrgyzstan participates in the Eurasian Economic Commission Council meeting in Moscow. The main focus is on expanding trade cooperation within the EAEU. The share of calculations in national currencies has already reached 93%, and Kyrgyzstan plans to use the USDKG stablecoin, which is backed by gold, in cross-border transactions. This could further strengthen the republic's position as an exporter and importer on the world stage.

subject: exports, imports, investment, FDI
english: Sber expanded the international payment geography for business. Now payments are available to more than 100 countries, and a round-the-clock VED support line is operational during weekdays. What the bank offers: assistance with document processing, selection of an individual route for complex VED transactions, consultations on foreign exchange control. Leave your request for payment on the website.

 2026 .

Logistan.info| |
english: Hyundai Rotem has sent the first of six ordered high-speed trains to Uzbekistan. The train, consisting of seven cars produced in South Korea for 'Uzbek Railways', is expected to arrive in January-February 2026. The remaining five trains (35 cars) are planned to be delivered by 2026. These trains were designed considering the climatic conditions of Uzbekistan and equipped with additional protection mechanisms against dust. LogiStan previously reported that in June 2024, 'Uzbek Railways' and Hyundai Rotem signed a contract for the supply of six high-speed trains to Uzbekistan and their subsequent maintenance. The deal was worth $200 million.

Chairman of the Committee for Transport and Logistics of the Union of Cement Producers "SOYUZCEMENT" and Director of Procurement and Logistics of A.O. "Cementros" Denis Nazarov spoke in an interview with InfraNews about the rapid departure of construction goods from the railway, why the measures taken by RZhD do not have a positive effect and even lead to an increase in the number of orders that are not supported by real loading.

Qarmet, Kazakhstan's largest steel producer, has started producing premium steel grades needed for the construction of nuclear power plants. In 2025, production increased from 260 to 350 types of steel. The project involves a Russian state corporation 'Rosatom' and is expected to cost between $14-15 billion.

subject: budget, investment, exports, imports, trade, infrastructure
english: In the West of Kazakhstan, four highways have been repaired. From January 2025, in the Western Kazakhstan region of Kazakhstan, 260 kilometers of state roads have been repaired. The projects include: reconstruction of the 'Podstepnoe - Fedorovka' highway (72 km), repair of the 'Unige - Bisen - Saihin' highway (103 km), intermediate repair of the road to the village Khantorda (21 km), and intermediate repair of the 'Aktobe - Uralsk' highway (64 km). The cost of these projects was not disclosed by KazAutZhol. Earlier, LogiStan reported that in 2025, Kazakhstan's government planned to allocate 598 billion tenge ($1.15 billion) for road repair and construction of 13 thousand kilometers.

The Ministry of Transport announced that the national railway operator plans to fully update its passenger train fleet by 2030. The ministry also mentioned acquiring 175 new passenger cars in 2025 and completing the renovation of 46 stations by the end of 2025.

original:
DP World

 DP World () , Ariana News.

 DP World - .

 , , .

 DP World .

 : DP World Tashkent Invest $288 

Logistan.info| |
english: Afganistan's authorities have handed over the Haxtaton and Torhram border crossings to DP World. The agreement includes modernizing the Haxtaton crossing with Uzbekistan and the Torhram crossing with Pakistan, under a public-private partnership. DP World will build new warehouses, install equipment for cargo inspection, and implement modern digital customs systems. No details on implementation timelines or costs were provided.

subject: exports, imports, investment, FDI
original:
Centrum Air AerCap Airbus A321neo

- AerCap Holding Centrum Air Airbus A321neo. 

 2027 .

 .

 Centrum Air 2023 - .

 : Centrum Air Avolon Airbus A320neo

Logistan.info| |
english: Centrum Air and the Irish-American AerCap Holding signed a contract for leasing two Airbus A321neo aircraft. The delivery is planned for Q4 2027. Centrum Air, established in 2023, has its headquarters in Tashkent. As of November 2025, the airline's fleet consisted of 13 aircraft.

subject: exports, imports, investment, FDI, industrial production, trade, employment, wages, budget, deficit, debt, inflation, interest rates, exchange rate
english: In the first 11 months of 2025, Kyrgyzstan's transport ministry identified 4,158 violations of weight and dimensional norms in road cargo transportation. Violators were fined $908,000 (up by 79% from a year ago). Also, for violating international transportation requirements, drivers were fined $142,000 (368 more cases than last year, with an increase of 3.2 times). The article also mentions that the volume of road cargo transport in Kyrgyzstan increased by 11%.

english: Anadolu Isuzu privatized SamAuto, an Uzbekistan auto plant, for $80 million. The Turkish company will invest another $80 million in the plant to produce buses and electric buses, as well as create service centers across Uzbekistan. The project's implementation timeline is not specified. Anadolu Isuzu plans to export these buses to Central Asia, South Caucasus, Middle East, and Africa.

Kazakhstan can only export up to 68 million tons of oil via the Caspian Pipeline Consortium (CPC) in 2025, which is 4 million tons or 5.6% less than planned. This was stated by Minister of Energy Eral Akkenzhanov. The reason for not meeting the plan is critical damage to one of three mobile unloading devices at the CPC terminal in the Caspian Sea due to attacks by Ukrainian unmanned boats on November 29, 2025.

subject: debt, budget, deficit, exports, imports, investment, FDI
english: Debt of Kazakhstani Railways has increased by $1.5 billion from the beginning of the year. Credit portfolio of Kazakhstani Railways is currently 3.7 trillion tenge ($7.104 billion). Ufuk Director for Finance Daier Kusherov said at a briefing that as of January 2025, credit debt has increased by 0.8 trillion tenge ($1.536 billion) or 27.6%. Also, Daier Kusherov announced that Kazakhstani Railways plans to go public in 2026.

The Russian Ministry of Transport withdrew a draft law requiring freight shippers to coordinate their transport requests with railway operators. This was explained by Denis Nazarov, Chairman of the Committee on Transport and Logistics at "SUEZCEMENT", who said that they submitted detailed objections to this initiative, outlined potential risks, and sent them to key institutions. As a result, the Ministry withdrew the draft for consideration and returned it for revision based on industry associations' opinions.

In the northwestern part of Kazakhstan, a logistics center is being built for $122.6 million. 'Kedentransservis' and 'TLK Tobol' are constructing a transport-logistics complex 'Tobol' with an area of 133.6 hectares in Kostanay city, Kostanay region. The project cost is 63.8 billion tenge ($122.6 million). Its capacity will be up to 400 thousand TEU (11 million tons of goods) per year. Regional authorities have not yet announced the expected date for the center's commissioning. It is expected that after its launch, the volume of freight transport in Kostanay region will increase by 20%. Logistan previously reported that according to IBC Global data, as of the third quarter of 2025, Kazakhstan has more than 2 million square meters of warehouse space. Of these, warehouses class A - 527 thousand square meters or 26.3% of Kazakhstan's total warehouse area.

Expected price growth of 5% and sales growth of 7% relative to 2025. To support business activity, 'Personal Trading Participant' service from Sber is launched, automating all stages of participation in state procurements: from selecting auctions and analyzing documents to applying for a guarantee from Sber. Expected to attract more than 400 new players by the end of 2025. However, the bank acknowledges that monetization of generative AI remains problematic with 80% costs on training. The entire market is looking for business models to make AI cost-effective and turn it into a source of income.

english: The government continues to compensate for the negative effects of a tough export ban on agriculture. A decision by Mikhail Mishustin from the reserve fund has allocated 60 billion rubles to banks for subsidizing low-interest loans. This will support payments on at least 48 thousand loans, which farms took not only for production and processing but also for veterinary drugs and purchasing agricultural equipment. Total state financing of agriculture in 2024-2025 is about 720 billion rubles. In 2025, the countryside received through mechanisms of subsidized funding 190 billion rubles, according to the premier. Systematic support by the government for rural areas has brought a noticeable effect - stability in grain production - annual volume from 2021-2025 is 140.3 million tons (+14.3% compared to 2016-2020), agricultural exports in 2025 are expected to increase to $51.2 billion (+6.5% year-over-year).

english: The Telegram message discusses the increase in luxury goods orders from other countries to Russia by 52% in 2025. It mentions that most premium products come from the USA and China, with some also coming through Belarus, Armenia, Kazakhstan, UAE, France, Italy, Germany, etc. The text also talks about the rise in import volumes due to increased purchasing power and higher prices for luxury goods like cosmetics and perfumes. It highlights the shift of business partnerships towards Eastern markets due to restrictions on imports from Western countries.

The European Commission will compile a list of countries that won't need to request prior approval for gas imports from the EU as part of an phased ban on Russian gas. The document introduces a pre-approval control mechanism: if it's not in place, importation will be automatically rejected and origin checks will be done before reaching the EU's customs territory. Exemptions are given to producers that the EU has already significantly imported from, and which either don't support Russia's gas sector (up to their own bans and restrictions) or lack infrastructure for importing Russian gas. Earlier it was agreed that the ban on Russian LNG would start at the end of 2026 and on pipeline gas in autumn 2027.

Attempts at additional identification are also being made for already blocked assets. It seems that European officials decided to compile a more complete database for further attempts at expropriation.

Azerbaijani border section will be delimited in Q1 2026 - Speaker. Can't say exactly about the area or the timing, think it will happen in the first quarter of next year', - stated Speaker of the National Assembly of Armenia A. Simonyan at briefing on Wednesday.

The problem occurred at a sewer collector on Zoravar Andranik Street. Crews are trying to fix it and have encountered difficulties because the manholes are under asphalt.
Armenian Prime Minister Nikol Pashinyan will travel from Hamburg to Moscow. There, he will participate in the Eurasian Economic Commission intergovernmental commission meeting.

A new emergency number 112 is being introduced in Armenia instead of the current numbers 1-02, 911, and 1-01. The previous numbers will temporarily function as a redirect to 112, with the latter eventually being phased out.

english: Levon Aronian won the Freestyle Chess final in Cape Town, South Africa. He defeated Magnus Carlsen of Norway with a score of 1.5:0.5. 'Aronian passed the Freestyle Chess tournament without losses! He is 43 years old but remains one of the strongest in the world,' writes chess.com. The current final stage of the Freestyle Chess Grand Slam Tour 2025 took place in Cape Town, South Africa from December 8-12. The prize fund is $660,000, with $200,000 going to the winner.

Unlocking communications in the region could strengthen its economic stability - Pashinyan. 'Positive changes happening in the region open new opportunities for deepening economic cooperation,' said Armenia's PM Nikol Pashinyan at a recent expanded Eurasian Council meeting in Moscow. In this context, he welcomed Azerbaijan's decision to unblock transit for goods heading to Armenia via Azeri territory. 'This is one of significant achievements in establishing peace and stability in our region,' said the Armenian PM.

Access to municipal kindergartens in Tbilisi will only be possible with electronic cards after the New Year holidays, starting January 15. Each family can get up to 8 cards. Also, for registered users, a one-time entrance QR code through the website www.tbilisikids.com will be available. Staff will also enter kindergartens only via an electronic security system. The agency managing children's centers reported that it has completed the implementation of the electronic access system in institutions. Electronic card readers and video surveillance systems have been installed.

The government of Georgia has decided to move all administrative buildings, starting with the parliament, out of the city center. A 'government town' is planned on what is known as 'Arsenal Hill', depicted in a famous painting by Georgian primitive artist Niko Pirosmani. The municipal development fund announced a tender for preparing general plans and sketches. Construction has not yet been scheduled - this article is not included in the 2026 budget. The total cost of the project is also unknown. However, some details are known: the plan emphasizes that the town should be integrated into the city structure and surrounded by an protective perimeter. This means creating a unified protected administrative cluster, according to media reports. The area planned for the government town extends up to 77 hectares. A total of 282,750 square meters of new office and administrative buildings will be constructed here. Parliament, administration of the government, city hall, SGB, and nine ministries: foreign affairs, economy, education, culture, infrastructure, regional development, social welfare, environmental protection, and agriculture are to move there. Up to 10,000 square meters will be reserved for reception areas for various events. The largest building will be the city hall of Tbilisi with a floor area of 59,900 square meters, while parliament will have a building with an area of 31,350 square meters. It is unclear what plans the government has regarding existing buildings whose functions are to be moved to Arsenal Hill. For example, will they be sold and at what price? The idea of constructing a government town is not new: it was first proposed by then Prime Minister Giorgi Kvirikashvili in 2017. At the end of last year, Prime Minister Kobakhidze decided to take up this issue.

A message from the third President of Georgia, Mikheil Saakashvili, in prison. He says he opened the doors to visitors and invites them inside R 12 - a club for Georgian political elites and intellectuals. The prison is overcrowded and chaotic with constant traffic in corridors. There are two main categories of prisoners: those who have not entered Saakashvili's parliament and those who support him. He describes the routine, including meetings with lawyers and the lack of proper food. He also mentions a prisoner who refuses to be near him but is kept at 7 steps away due to lack of trust. The message ends with a description of his time in prison and how he has been treated.

The Parliament of Georgia has accelerated the adoption of a new law that toughens rules for protest actions. The amendments to the Law on Meetings and Demonstrations and the Code of Administrative Offenses were prepared by ruling party 'Georgian Dream'. The new law requires notifying the Ministry of Internal Affairs Georgia five days in advance about planned demonstrations in places where people or transportation move, including sidewalks. Organizers who plan a demonstration without prior notification are prohibited. If police consider an event to be illegal, they have 15 minutes to disperse. After that, the entire gathering is considered illegal and authorities can take action under international law and Georgian laws. Violators face administrative detention up to 15 days (organizers up to 20 days), with repeat offenses leading to criminal proceedings with potential sentences of two years.

subject: budget, debt, employment, wages, industrial production, trade, exports, imports, investment, FDI
english: The ruling party 'Georgian Dream' is rapidly passing a law reforming higher education. Today, parliamentarians voted on it in the third and final reading. According to amendments, Georgia will transition to free state higher education. In the upcoming year, students entering first-year at state universities will all be taught for free. This does not apply to already enrolled students but during the transitional period, a temporary system of state scholarships that were awarded based on exam results will continue. State university programs will be reduced from three years to three years, master's programs one year, and doctoral studies will last three years. In 2025, over 7,300 applicants out of the 31,705 admitted students received state scholarships under the old system. The total scholarship fund was 11 million lari. Of this, 3.7 million lari went to private universities. Among state universities, Tbilisi State University led with 2,325 students receiving scholarships worth over 3.5 million lari. Transitioning to free higher education in state universities is part of a planned large-scale reform. In the future, the government plans to concentrate student life in Rustavi and Kutaisi, where they promise to build student dorms. Serious changes are expected for state universities the government intends to eliminate duplicate faculties based on the principle: one city-one faculty. Additionally, the government will introduce quotas for places on faculties based on market labor needs.

subject: budget, inflation, interest rates, exchange rate, reserves, current account, debt, employment, wages, industrial production, trade, exports, imports, investment, FDI
english: The Parliament of Georgia approved the budget for 2026 with a final vote of 80 to 9. The budget was prepared based on an economic growth forecast of 5%. Government expenditures in the next year will increase by 2.9 billion lari and reach 30.9 billion lari; tax revenues are expected to be 27 billion lari. Almost a third of all funds, 966 million lari, will go to the Ministry of Health and Social Protection, whose budget is projected to rise by 848.7 million lari. Military spending increases: the Defense Ministry's budget rises by 160 million lari, the Interior Ministry's by 152 million, and the State Security Service's by 128.5 million. The Education Ministry's budget, which has been restructuring throughout this year, decreases by 380 million lari due to a recent reform of education and free higher education. Debt load is expected to increase: in 2026, the country will borrow new obligations worth 506 million lari, mainly for infrastructure projects.

The visit of Israeli parliamentarians to Georgia has been canceled due to a threat of a terrorist attack, according to 'Echo Caucasus'. The parliamentarians were scheduled to participate in events during the 'Israel Week' in Georgia, including a Georgian-Israeli business forum. President of the Georgian-Israeli Business Chamber and founder of 'House Israel', Icyk Moshe, confirmed this information to 'Echo Caucasus'. He said that the 'Israel Week' will still take place in Tbilisi, but the parliamentarians may attend remotely. Moshe also reported that the threat information was passed on to the Georgian side. He expressed confidence that security measures for the event would be implemented. The SGB of Georgia has not yet commented.

National Environment Agency warns of severe weather conditions in Georgia starting tomorrow. From late afternoon on December 12th to morning on December 14th, heavy rain (occasionally strong) and snow (occasionally strong) are expected in western parts of the country, along with fog, blizzards, and icy roads. Strong winds will affect almost all of the country from December 13-14, with possible storm force winds up to level 5 at sea. Travel restrictions may be imposed on some road sections due to weather conditions.

The Georgian State Security Service (SSGB) denied media reports about the cancellation of Israeli parliament members' visit to Tbilisi due to a threat of terrorism. 'Neither Georgian nor Israeli security services had information about an impending terrorist attack in Georgia, and therefore did not share this information with anyone,' they said. The SSGB also stated that they support communication with representatives from Israel's intelligence community, who were 'surprised' by the spread of these messages. Earlier, media reported that members of the Knesset canceled their visit to Tbilisi, where they planned to participate in 'Israel Week.' It was claimed that information about the threat had been passed on by Israeli colleagues to Georgian counterparts.

Kobakhidze visited Ashgabat for the forum dedicated to International Year of Peace and Trust, as well as the 30th anniversary of Central Asian state's neutrality. He will speak at a plenary session titled 'Peace and trust: common goals for sustainable future' and hold several bilateral meetings.
@NGnewsgeorgia

Tbilisi will host the final of 'Children Eurovision' on December 13. This year, Georgia is represented by Anita Abgaryan with the song 'Shine like a star'. In total, there are representatives from 18 European countries in the finals. Voting for viewers will open today at midnight on the official website of the competition jesc.tv. You can vote for Anita Abgaryan from Georgia as well as any other part of the world. The final will be broadcast by Georgian Public Television starting at 20:00 on December 13. Georgia won after 11-year-old Andria Putkaradze's victory in Madrid in 2024. The government allocated 8,1 million lari for organizing the finals in Tbilisi. Georgia is the most successful country in 'Children Eurovision' history - since the competition debut in 2008, the country has won four times. This was last time Tbilisi hosted the event in 2017.

The updated Kveghevi-Kobi road to Upper Lars and Dariali will open in 2028. The 23-kilometer road near the Georgian-Russian border is expected to fully function in 2028, according to Deputy Minister of Infrastructure Mzia Giorgobiani. The project consists of two parts: a 9-kilometer tunnel that has already been drilled and internal works are underway. The second part includes tunnels and a unique arch bridge. Work on the second part is planned for completion in 2028, although it may be opened next year. The Kveghevi-Kobi road is an alternative route to the Kobisi-Gudauta section where avalanches often cause border closures during winter. After construction, travel time between Tbilisi and Gudauta will be reduced by 30 minutes (1 hour 30 minutes) and from Tbilisi to Stepanadzor it will take 1 hour 45 minutes instead of the current 2.5 hours.

The police of Georgia destroyed an unprecedented amount of drugs, totaling 926 kilograms. The value of the confiscated prohibited substances on what is called the 'black market' exceeds 19 million lari (over 7 million USD). Special high-temperature furnaces (insinerators) were used to destroy a large quantity of various types of narcotics, including: 'Cocaine', 'Heroin', 'Methadone', 'MDMA', 'Alpha-PVP', 'Ketamine', 'Clorazepate', 'Tramadol', 'Codeine', 'Diazepam', and 'Marijuana', as well as various psychotropic and new psychoactive substances. Drug consumption in Georgia has recently taken on epidemic proportions. In the first ten months of 2025, hundreds of local and foreign drug traffickers were arrested in the country. Police are constantly patrolling parks and nearby areas around Tbilisi, Batumi, Kutaisi to catch drug couriers or find so-called 'stash houses'. The Ministry of Internal Affairs and the Ministry of Finance have created a joint center for prevention, detection, and suppression of illegal drug trafficking.

A remote and mysterious site near Varziva, Georgia. It includes megalithic structures dating back to the Bronze Age (similar to Stonehenge), a medieval Orthodox church, and abandoned darbazi houses from the XVII-XVIII centuries. The location is described in detail.

Funny videos of students and teachers in Georgian schools have become popular on TikTok. The most popular video shows students surprising their teacher with a prank, which has thousands of variations.

A large construction project is planned in Georgia's capital: a government town will be built in the Chugureti area, on Gediashvili street (formerly 'Arsenalnyi Gorod'). The Fund for Municipal Development of Georgia announced a tender for services to prepare the master plan and design projects. The project includes building a parliament building, government administration, conference hall, Ministry of Foreign Affairs, among others. It also plans to build office buildings such as ministries of infrastructure, regional development, affairs of refugees, labor, health, social protection, economy and sustainable development, education, science and youth, culture, city administration, state security service, Georgia's State Minister's Office for reconciliation and civil equality. The main goal is to improve access to government services and create a modern, integrated space that will be fully integrated into the planned capital structure. Existing land should be developed so it becomes an integral part of the city and improves provision of public and social services, strengthens and optimizes inter-ministerial coordination, and organization and smooth operation of state and public events.

Mayor Kaka Kaladze announced on a city government meeting that the main New Year's tree in Tbilisi will be lit at 20:00 on December 12th. He emphasized efforts to create festive atmosphere for both children and adults, as last year's illumination ceremony on Rustaveli Square was canceled due to anti-government protests. The Christmas village was moved to the First Republic Square (where a bicycle monument is located) in December 2025.

Donor sperm caused a dangerous genetic syndrome: with it, 197 children were born across Europe, including in Georgia. The European sperm bank sold sperm from one donor in 14 countries, but recently it was found that some of his sperm cells contain genetic mutations, increasing the risk of developing malignant tumors to almost 100%. The man was healthy and passed all tests determining his suitability as a donor, but it turned out that DNA mutations occurred in some of his cells. This damaged the TP53 gene, playing a crucial role in fighting the development of cancerous cells. Some children have already been diagnosed with leukemia and other oncological diseases. 10 people died. Biological material from this man was used by women for approximately 17 years, including reproductive clinics in Georgia.

This message talks about Kutaisi, a city in Georgia. It mentions its unique atmosphere and attractions, such as the Magnolia over the Rioni River that signals springtime. The text also discusses how Kutaisi is becoming more accessible due to new direct flights from European cities and has been listed by New York Times as one of 52 places to visit in 2025. It highlights the city's rich history, culture, and notable landmarks like the Cathedral of St. Bartholomew and Jewish quarter with three synagogues.

subject: debt, exports, imports, investment, FDI
english: Russia is preparing a classification of difficult-to-extract oil and gas reserves. The Ministry of Natural Resources and the State Commission on Mineral Reserves (GKZ) sent a project to the Ministry of Finance. The goal of the document is to create a unified system for evaluating fields that require complex technologies. Currently, there are no common criteria, which complicates production planning and support of projects. The classification will consider technological and economic complexity in project design and tax incentives. It's expected to boost development of Bajtsovskiy formation, Achimov formations, and high-viscosity oil fields, which make up a significant part of the country's resource base.

The OFAC (Office of Foreign Assets Control) renewed the license that allows deals with Lukoil and its affiliates, including Lukoil International GmbH and their subsidiaries holding more than 50% stake. Lukoil was sanctioned by USA on October 22. The company announced plans to sell foreign assets worth $20-24 billion. Potential buyers include Chevron, ExxonMobil, Carlyle Group, ADNOC, IHC, Todd Boeley investor and Austrian businessman Bernd Bergmayr.

english: MTS became the undisputed leader of Russia's Private LTE market. Telecom Daily reports that from 2018 to November 2025, MTS implemented 69 projects and took up 43% of the market. Second place is held by MegaFon (56 projects), third by Rostelecom (7 projects). In 2025, MTS also maintained its leadership: 19 projects, which accounts for 45% of all Private LTE deployments since the beginning of the year. The main drivers of the market are industry, energy, mining, transportation, and agriculture sectors where Private LTE is used as a basis for digitalization and platform for Edge analytics, IoT, and equipment management. Market trends: transition to Russian technologies, growth in government support, integration with AI, expansion of scenarios with the arrival of p5G. More projects are appearing among medium-sized businesses and tech parks thanks to SaaS approach. Annual stable growth forecasted at 25-30% and shift from individual deployments to mass industrial projects.

President of Serbia Aleksandar Vui announced worsening energy situation and expected sanctions against Serbia. He confirmed Serbia's commitment to EU membership, despite internal resistance. Vui expressed dissatisfaction with the new gas agreement with Russia, which expires in 2025, linked to risks around NIS.

Work with foreign partners in the EDI system (Electronic Data Interchange). Simplify transactions by moving document exchange to an electronic format. It's fast, convenient and reduces errors in paperwork. Documents are signed electronically by each party and have legal force in both countries.

Currently, there are few operators of the EDI system that allow exchanging legally significant documents with foreign partners in Russia and many legislative barriers exist. But solutions are available.

For example, KONTUR (Diadok, Extern) has launched cross-border EDI with Kazakhstan and Belarus. Also, KONTUR services will help work with customs, product marking, and tracking such goods.

All system capabilities on the KONTUR channel.

Roboticization in Russia is accelerating, but high interest rates and localization could derail ambitious plans. Industrial robot density in Russian industry grows faster than world averages and by 2025 will increase to 40 robots per 10,000 workers. However, the president's goal of entering the top-25 countries globally by this indicator by 2030 is at risk due to high central bank interest rates, localization requirements, and lack of investments. Key barriers: High central bank rate makes depositing money more attractive than investing in robots. Localization requirements for hardware increase costs and component shortages. Implementation of the federal project is lagging significantly.

The Federal Council approved a law to extend until December 31, 2027, the permission for importing and selling drugs in original foreign packaging. This measure is applied during shortages or risks of their occurrence due to sanctions. Conditions remain unchanged: medications must comply with registration requirements in Russia, and an informational sticker should be placed on Russian language.

Russian electronics manufacturers are demanding 'special conditions' for a planned technology tax starting September 1, 2026. They want the tax to apply only to imported finished products (smartphones, laptops) but not to components and Russian-made goods. This is to prevent domestic producers from being undercut by the market and high-interest loans.

The countries of the Eurasian Economic Union (EAEU) are simplifying their tax system for online purchases and reducing customs duties. The customs duty on goods above this amount will be reduced from 15% to 5%. Key changes include splitting payments: a 5% customs fee will be charged at the union level, while VAT will be applied according to each country's rate. This simplifies administration and makes rules more transparent for buyers. Final approval of the new mechanism is expected in the near future.

Russian fashion brands are losing revenue due to imperfect websites. Sales through their own online stores bring Russian fashion retailers only about 10% of their revenue, which is two to three times less than leading global networks. The main reason: technical imperfections on the sites - slow loading on mobile devices (over 70% of traffic), broken search, complicated buying process. Each extra second of loading reduces conversion by 5-10%. What should be considered:
1. Dominance of marketplaces in Russia is an anomaly. Brands build sales around their own channels worldwide. Leaving for marketplaces stripped them of control, margins and direct connection with customers.
2. Own website - path to independence and profit. Against the backdrop of rising commissions and fines on marketplaces, a channel becomes a strategic asset for increasing profitability and managing assortments.
3. Technical shortcomings are direct losses. Simple UX improvements (search, fixed buy button) can instantly increase sales by 5-10%. In the face of pressure from marketplaces, Russian retail must make up lost ground and invest in quality digital to regain control over business and customers.

Russia has developed equipment for 65 nm microchips, but the development program is underfunded by tens of billions. The NIIME and NITME (part of the 'Element' group) have created Russia's first cluster-based deposition and etching facilities that allow producing chips with topological norms of 65 nm. This puts Russian institutes among the five world leaders in creating such equipment, marking a key step towards technological independence in microelectronics. The program for electronic machinery development is systematically underfunded. In 2024-2025, actual funding was two to three times less than planned. This threatens the implementation of dozens of projects and nullifies breakthrough successes without proper investments for serial deployment and transition to new nodes will be halted.

english: China is creating a joint venture with Rolls-Royce for aircraft engine maintenance and repair, highlighting the problem in Russian aviation industry. In Beijing, an Air China-Rolls-Royce joint venture opened to service and repair modern jet engines. By 2034, the factory will repair 250 engines per year, closing China's strategic dependence on this high-tech sector. This event is a mirror reflecting one of Russia's most acute problems in aviation industry. While China already has its own engines (C919), it is expanding its capabilities through technology transfer to service and repair Western models. After 2022, Russia faced a complete gap in such chains. Modern aviation is not just production but also a deep, lifelong maintenance ecosystem (MRO). Without this, even successful engines like PD-14 cannot be guaranteed or profitable on the entire fleet. Developing service for domestic engines and creating a full independent maintenance network (including repair of imported equipment remaining in the country) a task no less important than developing new models. This is not only about technology but also business model currently actively being built in China, but remains a risk area in Russia.

Hollywood companies have warned about risks to the industry and demanded regulators block the agreement. President Donald Trump noted that Netflix already controls a significant market share which will increase after the acquisition. Paramount also joined the fight, offering $100 billion in cash against Netflix's $82.7 billion offer. They want to acquire Warner Bros. Discovery, including its assets and networks like CNN and TNT Sports. Netflix proposes to buy part: the film studio and streaming services as well as HBO. Paramount considers a possible solution allowing two streaming companies (Netflix and HBO) to merge anti-competitive.

Russian luge athletes Savely Korostelev and Daria Nepryayeva, as well as freestyle skier Anastasiya Tatalya, were approved for a neutral status by the International Federation of Skiing (FIS). The athletes can participate in selection competitions for the Olympics in Italy. Korostelev previously left for Switzerland's Davos, where the World Cup stage will take place.

english: The general director of Alfa-Savings, Vladimir Skvortsov, during a speech at the "New Economy" forum, discussed with regulators about possible insurance for business responsibility in case of data leaks under cyber-insurance. They discuss compensation from insurance part of the penalty for personal data leakage. They understand that the fine is punishment and cannot be insured. But if there is no client's fault when the leak occurs despite information protection measures, they think that a part of the sum, for example 25%, could be compensated.

The qualification commission of Moscow Bar Association rejected the Ministry of Justice's request to terminate the status of lawyers Julia Tai, Alexei Basistov, and Dmitry Provodin, who previously worked at Bartolius office. Two sources familiar with the commission's conclusions and confirmed by Julia Tai told RBC about this.

Vladimir Putin relieved Oleg Khramov of his position as Deputy Secretary of the Russian Security Council and appointed Maxim Kutomin to this post. The position of Secretary of the Security Council is held by Sergey Shoigu.

Evening on December 10, the main Christmas tree of the country will be delivered to Moscow Kremlin. A special train will bring it through Spasskiye Vorota, which opens only for the most solemn occasions, at 22:00 on December 10. The tree will decorate Sparrow Hills Square until January 20. An ancient tree with a height of 26 m was cut in Ruzsky Municipal District of Moscow Oblast on December 8. Traditionally, the selection of trees began in summer and lasted several months. This year, there were 24 candidates for the main Christmas tree spot. How they choose it and how have the trees changed on Sparrow Hills Square over the past ten years in RBC article.

Moscow City Court has rejected the appeal of Vadim Mozhkovitch, founder of 'Rusagro' group and former company CEO Maxim Basov. The judge did not approve the extension of their detention period. The defendants' lawyers asked for a change in the measure to house arrest. One of Mozhkovitch's lawyers said his enterprise is ready to pay a 1 billion rubl bail. Lawyers also mentioned 'fishing' tactics by investigators and 'unreasonable accusations.'

The renovation program launched in Moscow in 2017, over the years has transformed from a targeted project for upgrading old buildings into an instrument of systemic transformation of the city's environment. It involved more than 5,000 old buildings where about one million people live. As of now, relocation has affected more than 235,000 residents. In the next three years, the program will cover another 215,000 residents. We look at what new technologies have appeared in the process of upgrading outdated Moscow residential stock.

Discussing Russian sellers' complaints to foreign sellers on marketplaces. Items are copied, commissions for foreign players are lower, mandatory labeling is not required. What needs to be changed in the rules to maintain fair competition? Listen live

A court in Sverdlovsk Oblast fined a 20-year-old resident of Kamensk-Uralsky city, Sergey Glukhikh, 3,000 rubles for violating an administrative article on searching extremist materials. This is the first court decision on such case. The lawyer, Sergey Barsukov, said they will appeal this ruling as it's considered illegal.

The Hermitage demands compensation of over 800,000 rubles from a man who sat on the throne of the Maltese Order and placed his feet on the side bench. The incident occurred on March 21, 2025. The man allegedly violated museum rules by causing serious damage to valuable exhibits. Two artifacts - the throne and the side bench - date back to the XVIII century and belonged to Emperor Paul I. Damage includes deformation of the seat, tearing of the velvet fabric, cracks and tears in the velvet fabric under the bench. The Hermitage estimates restoration costs at 825,813.59 rubles. It also seeks reimbursement for court fees of 21,516 rubles. The man did not respond to a pre-litigation claim. A preliminary hearing is scheduled on January 26, 2026.

Russia has recruited over 400,000 military personnel and 34,000 volunteers this year. Deputy Chairman of the Security Council Dmitry Medvedev said that the recruitment targets have been almost reached.

Premier Mikhail Mishustin said at the cabinet meeting that the government needs to prepare additional measures promptly to improve Russia's demographic situation. The president Vladimir Putin included preparations for additional comprehensive measures in reversing the downward demographic trend as one of the tasks the government should resolve by 2026. Mishustin expects proposals on improving Russia's demographic situation from the government by June 2026, highlighting that it is important to choose methods with the best results and then work out their national-level implementation.

Russia and the UAE have at least eight areas of cooperation in the next few years. This was stated by the head of Russia's Ministry of Industry and Trade Anton Alimov and the Minister of Economy and Tourism of the UAE Abdululla Bin Tuk Al-Marr in the first Russian-UAE business forum in Dubai, as reported by RBC. Russia listed the following areas for cooperation:
 Heavy industry in the energy complex
 Pharma
 High technologies
 Investments and tourism
 Food production
 Tourism
 FinTech and financial services
Space.
According to Al-Marr, meetings over the past two days showed that the countries already have interactions in all these areas.

english: A drop of 10% in Moscow new construction demand for the first half of 2025. The Russian real estate market development and priorities for developing new Moscow districts were discussed by Andrey Likhachev, General Director of A.O. "SZ 'Rublevo-Archangelskoe'".

A notary scheme: Notaries proposed measures to protect homebuyers. From 2025, the obligatory notarization of gift contracts shifted fraudsters' attention to real estate purchases. In response, notaries suggest several tools that could reduce risks on the housing market. - Introduce the principle of a notarial transaction's indefeasibility: a good-faith buyer is protected; only through a special procedure can the contract be challenged, with compensation for losses by the notary. - Improve notary insurance: increase minimum insurance amounts (currently 5 million rubles), expand the list of insured events and compensation limits. - Introduce a cooling-off period of up to 14 days between contacting a notary and signing the contract, controlled by the notary, so that the owner can weigh their decision.

The State Duma proposed to cancel annual declarations of officials. This makes it possible to abandon the outdated annual spring system of control and significantly reduce the time needed for analyzing incoming data and timely taking measures against 'any corruption violations'. He also emphasized that it is important to protect personal data from being used for blackmail, extortion, and other illegal actions.

subject: debt, reserves, current account, budget, deficit, debt
english:
Can you return money for a gift certificate? Money on a gift certificate or card does not expire and can be returned, but there are exceptions. Although many buyers believe that it is impossible to cash in the certificate or return the money after its expiration period. In Roskachestvo they explained that there are several types of gift cards:

discounts given for free to customers. They may have special rules and it's unlikely you can cash them out;

purchasable with flexible denomination. You can cash them in or pay at the store, even if the card has expired.

Lawyers explained that such a certificate is considered an advance. If the expiration period of the card has passed and (or) there are still funds left on it, you want to return them, then refusal by the store to accept the card for payment or urging to buy goods in full according to law will be considered illegal enrichment and infringement of consumer rights.

How to return money from a gift certificate:
1. Go to the store and tell the seller about your desire to exchange the card or certificate for cash.
2. If the seller refuses, present the store with your written request for a refund of funds. Written complaints rarely leave stores without an answer.
3. If the store does not accept the complaint or does not meet the requirements in it for a refund of money, you can submit a lawsuit.

The European Court of Justice rejected Alexander Pumpanian's lawsuit against the EU Council for 7.5 million in compensation for non-enforcement of previous court decisions to lift sanctions. The businessman demanded reimbursement for both material and moral damages from the EU Council, which had not enforced three court rulings since 2023. He claimed he proved a real and credible damage and causal link between the Council's actions and alleged harm. However, the court found that the plaintiff did not present any evidence to justify the requested compensation amount.

english: Donor sperm, which carried a mutation in the TP53 gene leading to cancer, fathered at least 197 children across several European countries. Some of them have inherited the mutation and developed cancer; there are also fatal cases of cancer, according to an investigation by the European Broadcasting Union, which includes major media outlets from European countries. Details are published in Denmark Radio and Swedish TV. In 2005, a Danish student became donor number 7069 at the European Sperm Bank (ESB) in Copenhagen, one of the largest institutions worldwide in this field. At that time, neither he nor ESB knew about the mutation. Later, it was found that up to 10-19% of sperm from Kielde carried the TP53 mutation. This gene functions as a suppressor (anti-oncogene) and inhibits the formation of malignant tumors. The donor himself is considered healthy, being simply a carrier, but the mutation significantly increases the risk of childhood cancers such as leukemia, brain tumors, and bone cancer in offspring.
Main news of the evening on TV channel RBC.
Russian air defense systems shot down 31 Ukrainian drones in 5 hours over Russian regions, reported the Ministry of Defense.

Moscow has successfully restructured the tourism industry despite sanctions and severed ties with Western countries, as reported by American Forbes. The publication notes a strategic shift towards tourists from Asia and the Middle East, which Moscow uses as a tool of 'soft power':

"Moscow demonstrates that it can independently develop innovations without relying on Western institutions or stock markets [..]. Now, it wants to differentiate itself from the West and attract Arab, Chinese, and Indian guests."

In 2023, Russia welcomed about 2.3 million foreign tourists, mainly from China, India, Turkey, and Iran, as well as a sharp increase in travelers from Southeast Asia, countries of the Persian Gulf, and Central Asia, filling the void left by European visitors. By the first half of 2025, the tourism flow grew by 10% annually.

"Russia bets that tourists visiting Moscow will take away an image (and message) of a high-tech megacity not inferior to anything in China or Western Europe," Forbes.

The TV channel TNT premiered a new year's film, which included shots of singer Larisa Dolina singing 'For money - yes' under the song. The premiere took place at the October Cinema, as reported by RBC. "Komsomolskaya Pravda" wrote that Dolina is being removed from New Year programs due to a scandal with her apartment. Sources said this affected already recorded shows. In summer 2024, Dolina sold her apartment in Khimki under the influence of fraudsters and then won a court ruling declaring the sale invalid. subject: inflation, interest rates, employment, wages, industrial production, trade, exports, imports, investment, FDI
english: The Federal Reserve (Fed) cut the rate for the third time in a row and lowered it to its lowest level in three years. The Fed reduced the target rate by 25 basis points to 3.5-3.75% per year. This is the lowest since November 2022. The regulator stated that existing indicators indicate moderate economic activity growth. Employment growth slowed this year, and unemployment rose slightly in September. More recent data align with these trends. Inflation has risen compared to the beginning of the year and remains at a higher level. The Fed noted that they are closely monitoring risks related to both sides of their mandate and believe that job risk increased recently. The decision coincided with market expectations and analysts' forecasts. The regulator also cut rates by 25 b.p. on two consecutive meetings before this one. Next, the Fed meeting is scheduled for January 27-28, 2026. Experts expect that in January, the Fed will take a short pause and then make another two steps to reduce the rate by 25 b.p. starting from March.

RBC presents the second season of documentary film 'Wine Time: People'. The shooting team focused on Krasnodar Krai as one of Russia's leading wine producers. For the second year in a row, the minivan VOYAH DREAM has been a reliable companion for the 'RBC Wine' expedition. The team covered more than 2,000 kilometers on it. The trip was comfortable due to adaptive pneumatic suspension with active shock absorber control, spacious cabin with individual seats in the second row equipped with heating, ventilation and massage systems, and a total driving range of over 900 km (according to WLTP cycle) with a full tank and fully charged battery. No matter what weather conditions or how far you have to travel, VOYAH is an excellent choice for trips to wineries.
