english: Russian banks are not rushing to ease mortgage conditions despite a reduction in the central bank's rate and an increase in demand for them. In November 2025, the share of rejections on mortgage credit applications reached 69.2%, which is the highest level over the past year, according to data from the National Credit History Bureau (NKB), which was analyzed by RBC. Another sign of a cautious stance by creditors is their reluctance to lower the cost of housing loans. The average interest rate for mortgages in top-20 banks has remained at 21.2121.25% since October, according to data from 'Dom.RF'. At the same time, from a market perspective, the market shows an increase: according to Frank RG, the volume of provided loans is growing month by month, in November it reached 496.3 billion rubles. A significant part of the issuance falls on subsidized programs, but growth is also observed in the segment of market mortgages. Why are creditors so strict towards potential mortgage applicants and when should changes be expected in RBC's material.

Overnight, Russian air defenses intercepted 287 Ukrainian drone aircraft. 118 were destroyed over Bnska Oblast, 40 over Kaluzhskaya Oblast, and another 40 over Moscow region. 27 drones were shot down in Tula Oblast, 19 in Novgorod Oblast, 11 in Yaroslavskaya Oblast, 10 in Lipetsk Oblast, 6 each in Kursk and Oryol Oblasts, and 4 each in Voronezh and Ryazan Oblasts.

Commission increases on major platforms like Ozon and WB have risen significantly in some categories. Marketplaces attribute this to comparable rises in fuel costs, logistics, warehouse rentals, IT infrastructure, personnel, as well as tax burden. Commission hikes do not lead to a similar rise in product prices, which can be partially avoided by marketplaces' investments in increasing discounts on products. However, increased commissions and simultaneous control of low product price through discounts contribute to sellers losing revenue from goods, and their price is lower than in other sales channels. This makes it harder for entrepreneurs to develop their business outside marketplaces.

How do commission increases affect sellers? In RBC's overview.

In this hour, Radio RBC is discussing the main issues in Russian business. Today, patients consider not only the level of equipment and doctor's qualifications at a clinic, but also evaluate the service and format of provided services. Among key criteria: comfort in interacting with staff, organization of the registration process and document handling for appointments, as well as online communication with healthcare institutions. Digital services help improve the client scenario by automating routine questions. For example, F.Doc's paperless office helps simplify patient interactions through online document processing. The service makes signing documents easy and appointment procedures gentle. More about using F.Doc in clinics.

Belgium asks the EU to create an additional monetary buffer in response to Russia's retaliatory measures against plans to use frozen Russian assets for supporting Ukraine. This is according to Politico citing documents. The creation of a monetary reserve is part of a series of amendments Belgium wants to include in the proposal from the European Commission about using Russian assets. It will be funded by excess profits Euroclear receives as interest on blocked Russian assets, which amounted to 4 billion last year. The buffer will complement financial guarantees EU countries provide to Belgium under a 210 billion credit. Their goal is to protect Brussels from having to individually return the entire amount if Russia succeeds in compensation for seized assets.

Kazakh Foreign Minister Ermek Kocherbayev discussed with the Ukrainian side attacks on the Caspian Pipeline Consortium in Novorossiysk. The video of the press conference is published by 'Sputnik'.

"With Ukraine, there is understanding," said Kocherbayev about the strikes against KTC.

In the night of November 29, unmanned boats attacked the sea terminal of KTC, resulting in serious damage to the VPU-2 mooring device. Further operation of VPU-2 is impossible, loading has been suspended.

Kazakhstan then decided to urgently redirect the export flow of oil to alternative routes. The Ministry expressed protest to Ukraine, emphasizing that bilateral relations have suffered a blow. Kyiv in response stated that it had taken into account Kazakhstan's concern about the situation at KTC, adding that it acts within Article 51 of the UN Charter, providing for the right of members of the organization to self-defense.

A floating device (VPU-2) of the Caspian Pipeline Consortium in Novorossiysk, damaged by Ukrainian unmanned boats in November, has received significant damage. The size of the hole is three and a half meters wide by two meters long. Kazakhminister Eryl Akkenjenov told journalists. 'The consortium is restoring buoyancy; once it's restored, we will know whether it needs to be repaired or not.' RBC in Telegram and MAX

english: A high-ranking Ukrainian official said that the latest version of the US peace plan does not include the withdrawal of Russian troops from eastern parts of Donbas. The Financial Times reported this news. Initially, Trump's peace plan with 28 points included a proposal to create a 'neutral demilitarized buffer zone' after Ukraine withdraws its forces from Donbas. The newspaper called territorial issues a serious obstacle that could scuttle the peace deal. Russia and the US demand that Kyiv fully withdraw its troops from Donbas. Several sources in Donald Trump's administration, including Special Envoy to the United States Steve Wooldridge, have been insisting on 'territory exchange' as an inevitable part of any peace deal between Kyiv and Moscow in recent weeks. Ukrainian officials participating in negotiations said that the US is pushing for a similar demilitarized zone dividing North and South Korea. However, according to Ukrainian leader Volodymyr Zelenskyy, this leads not to a lasting peace but to frozen conflict, as reported by FT.

english: On the forum 'New Economy', they discussed the development of Russian industry and the dynamics of digital transformation in the sector. Among the key topics: industrial growth stability, import substitution effect, prospects for Russian IT products, and changes in approaches to enterprise digital security. Pavel Rastopshin, CEO of Ulymateg Group, noted that demand for Russian IT solutions in industry is growing by about 30% in 2025 enterprises are accelerating the transition from foreign software to domestic developments, balancing safety and innovative development tasks. The main driver of growth was April changes in 187FZ, requiring enterprises to categorize standard KII objects defined by the state. He also emphasized that digital projects already provide a noticeable economic effect from reducing downtime and optimizing repairs to implementing joint industry solutions formed through partnerships between manufacturers and technological companies. 'Import substitution can be innovative' he said.

A second solar plasma release reached Earth on December 11. This caused magnetic storms, which hit the planet around 0:00-6:00 and had a geomagnetic index KP of 6.33, corresponding to a moderate magnetic storm. The article also mentions that whether it will continue and how strong it differs from magnetic field disturbances since January 2025 is shown in an infographic by RBC.

Result of the incident at Perm Polytechnic University resulted in two deaths, including a minor. A criminal case has been opened under Article 109 (causing death by negligence to two persons) of the Criminal Code. It was established that on December 11, 2025, in one of the laboratories in the city of Perm, a gas leak occurred. As a result of the incident, a man and an 8-year-old girl died, while 2 others were injured. On-site investigation is underway.

Ex-Soviet advisor to the US president, scientific researcher at the American Council on International Relations Thomas Graham proposed creating working groups in Russia, USA, Ukraine and EU for Ukrainian settlement. In his article for Foreign Affairs he emphasized that only Washington can lead these efforts.

During early Western media reports about Trump's peace plan, Thomas Graham visited Moscow during which he gave an interview to RBC about prospects and main directions of consultations on conflict resolution.

The success of the initiative will depend on Donald Trump administration's readiness for long-term and complex diplomatic work as well as on the ability to involve Kyiv and European partners in the process. The proposed scheme envisages several parallel groups that should deal with key issues: territorial disputes, security guarantees and mechanisms for stopping hostilities.

Different combinations of participants can be included in individual groups. For example, nuclear questions may be discussed in a format of USA-Russia, territorial ones involving Moscow, Kyiv and Washington, while European security issues will require the presence of EU representatives.

english: The level of morbidity in Russia from influenza and other respiratory illnesses has not exceeded the typical levels for an autumn-winter season and is related to the natural course of the epidemic process. The main specialist in infectious diseases at the Ministry of Health Vladimir Chulanov stated this on RBC. From December 1st to 7th, the morbidity rate was 94.6 cases per 10 thousand people. This is a 20% increase from the previous week, he added. 'Despite an increase in influenza and other respiratory illnesses in Russia, expected continuation of the trend over the next few weeks, observed situation does not exceed typical autumn-winter season levels and is related to the natural course of the epidemic process as well as increased contacts among the population before New Year holidays', Chulanov emphasized.

Ukrainian President Vladimir Zelensky said Ukrainians should express their opinion on whether Ukraine retains control of the controlled part of Donbas. This is reported by RBC-Ukraine.

'In an election format or referendum, but a Ukrainian position must be expressed,' he said. 'The US position is to withdraw Ukrainian forces from Donbas and create a demilitarized zone, but the question of who will manage this territory has not been resolved, Washington seeks some format.'

'Our position: it's fair when we are where we are, at the contact line. Therefore, there are different positions between these formats, and discussions continue, which is still undefined.'

Traffic jams in Moscow reached level 10, according to data from the 'Yandex Maps' service. This situation occurred on December 19, 2024. The Moscow transport department recommends postponing car trips until 8 PM MSK.

The stock market rose after Zelensky's words about a referendum on territorial issues in Ukraine. At the peak at 19:11 Moscow time, the MOEX index (IMOEX2) increased by 2.17%, to 2780.95 points. This was the highest since mid-September. Source: 'Smartlab'. Subscribe to 'You Are an Investor!'

What products will form the Sber ecosystem? How does Sber evoke positive emotions? And what new services became available these are among the topics that First Deputy Chairman of the Board of Sberbank Kirill Tsaryev talked about.

International Olympic Committee (IOC) recommended allowing Russian and Belarusian junior athletes to participate in international sports competitions, including team events. Also, standard protocols of international federations will be applied regarding flags, anthems, forms, etc., provided that the corresponding national sporting organization is in good standing. International federations themselves set criteria for what they consider 'junior competitions', but participation should be ensured without additional restrictions in all individual and team events. These rules, subject to the restoration of ROC, will apply to the Junior Olympics in Dakar 2026.

english: Vice Prime Minister and Finance Minister of Belgium Vincent Van Peteghem said that frozen Russian assets in Europe may have to be used for financing Ukraine. He also stated that Belgium will not make any reckless compromises until a deal is reached on this matter. The EU has been discussing the possibility of providing Ukraine with a 'reparatory loan' using blocked Russian assets since September. In early December, the European Commission approved two options for funding Kiev, one of which is a 'reparatory loan'. According to Politico, it involves 25 billion from frozen Russian assets in private banks across the eurozone and 140 billion from Belgium's Euroclear depositary, where most of these assets are stored.

english: Palm oil will remain without reforms. The government refused to tighten control over its use. Previously, lawmakers had proposed improving regulation: mass consumption of such oil may be harmful for health, they believe. Among other things lawmakers suggested introducing a tax on imported oil, banning it in dairy products, and making the supervisory bodies more transparent. The Cabinet considered that existing legislation already adequately regulates product safety, and claims about the harm caused by palm oil are not proven and contradicted by several authoritative studies. Pensions were discussed in the broadcast of TV channel RBC.
90% of Russian films' budget is funded by the state, according to documents from the Film Fund and Ministry of Culture. What happened with Russia's film industry in 2025 we have cards.

A summary of the Trump peace plan and developments related to Russia, Ukraine, and Europe. Topics include: a former Bush advisor's proposal for working groups; Russian Foreign Minister Lavrov's readiness to sign a document guaranteeing no attack on Europe; removal from the US peace plan of the requirement for Russia to withdraw troops from the so-called demilitarized zone; Ukrainian President Zelensky's possibility of holding a referendum on withdrawing forces from Donbas; White House disappointment with Russia and Ukraine; Trump urging German, French, and British leaders to pressure Zelensky to accept US peace plan conditions. This includes territorial concessions by Kyiv and limiting its army size.

The Moscow Exchange plans to appeal the court decision that took ownership of Solikamsk Magnesium Plant (SMZ) shares from private investors. UBS Director Elena Kuritsyna told journalists, 'We plan to appeal the cassation decision by SMZ, asking to leave in force the appellate court's ruling recognizing the minority shareholders' purchases as legal.' The Solikamsk Magnesium Plant is a company in Perm Krai. In 1992 it was privatized and three decades later, in August 2022, the Prosecutor General filed an action declaring the deal illegal. The case became precedent for Russia's market because it was the first time that investors had their shares taken from the exchange, not through direct deals (10.6%). In October, a third round of dispute around SMZ shares - the decision to take shares from investors was supported by cassation court. After this, a group of minority shareholders and the CB appealed the decision to the Supreme Court.

The CBR initially proposed a limit of up to 5 cards per bank and up to 20 in total per person. The document is currently being revised together with the Ministry of Digital Development and the government. The draft has not yet been submitted to the State Duma, but it may be considered before this session.

A member of the faction 'New People' in the State Duma, Dmitry Pevtsov made a series of resonant statements that clearly do not correspond to the image and spirit of the party defenders of common sense, as they call themselves. In an interview with TASS, the Russian actor said he is sure that by 2031 'we will all be resting in Odessa', called most of the created TV series 'organized satanism' and urged to abolish state interference in creative processes. It's unlikely that founder and leader of the party Alexey Nechayev was delighted with these statements, but he can't do anything about Pevtsov. For the actor, elected as a self-nominated candidate, and incorporated into the faction 'New People' in 2021 - to be able to quickly collapse the party's rating if necessary. And for the progressive liberal urban electorate, for whom this party was created with direct participation of the AP, it will seriously believe that 'New People' is a self-sufficient political force and give too many votes (more than they are allocated by political administrators on Old Square). One of the key tasks of the AP in the 2026 State Duma elections is to ensure that the second place for LDPR. Therefore, it cannot be allowed that 'New People' will get more votes than party Sluchskogo. But third place for 'New People' does not suit the AP to not offend Zyuganov. To allow the Nechayev party to limp somewhere near the five percent barrier by September 2026, we will hear from Pevtsov many interesting things.

A remarkable case where the state itself provokes corruption and excludes civil society from controlling officials. Essentially, society is no longer a subject to the state and bureaucracy but an external observer. By removing public participation in anti-corruption procedures, reliance shifts to 'information vacuum' by FSB (Federal Security Service). However, this vacuum (emphasis on information collection rather than data) does not effectively combat corruption but strengthens the power of the security corporation, manipulates information, and intensifies non-legal intra-elitist competition. Piskaev misleads everyone: public declaration of property is a direct demonstration of an official's honesty, institutional trust and control by social institutions over the state. Thus, public transparency of an official's financial situation legitimates society's trust in them. Other 'Poseidon' and ORM (Operational Information Gathering) are operational information collection from security structures. They can exist parallelly within criminal procedural law. Operator and controller here are exclusively security structures; society is a passive consumer of filtered information (data from Poseidons will be classified). Thus, civil society has been demonstratively excluded as a controller, moving to the gallery spectator role. Hence, everything is in the hands of the state; transparency is completely eliminated. How candidates for corruption will be chosen - this is a guessing game. Also, declaration for an official is presumption of innocence. That is, by declaring income and assets, an official confirms their own good order status on their own, and then security forces must investigate all nuances to expose them in corruption. If they lied or made mistakes, strict punishment follows. This is a crucial psychological aspect - honest disclosure of information about oneself as a servant of the state, thus also society's trust. In the new system, an official is relieved from annual reporting; everything reduces to good order within the system that will notice or not. Thus, an official has no public history and public responsibility.

subject: budget, debt, exports, investment, FDI, industrial production, trade, employment, wages, reserves, deficit, GDP, inflation, interest rates, exchange rate, current account, budget, investment, FDI
english: The state continues to support the economy and its basic industries by compensating for negative effects of a tough DP. The decision by Mikhail Mishustin from the reserve fund allocated 60 billion rubles to banks for subsidizing low-interest loans for agriculture. This will help support payments on at least 48,000 loans taken not only for production and processing but also for veterinary medicines and equipment acquisition. Total state financing of agricultural production in 2024-2025 is about 720 billion rubles, including 190 billion rubles in 2025 through subsidized mechanisms, according to the premier. Systematic support by the government for agriculture has brought noticeable effects: stable grain production - annual volume from 2021-2025 is 140.3 million tons (+14.3% compared to 2016-2020), export of agricultural products in 2025 increased to 51.2 billion dollars (+6.5% year-over-year). The paradox lies in the fact that budgetary funds are recycled through banks, guaranteeing them substantial income, while the central bank does not plan to abandon high key interest rates, which forces the state to spend large amounts on maintaining financial stability for agriculture and other priority industries. Banks receive up to 13-14% of budgetary subsidies per each subsidized loan without any efforts. An alternative to subsidizing intermediaries through the state budget is digital ruble funding with government guarantees. It's unclear why the Ministry of Finance does not initiate a transition to such financing methods for national priorities, although it plans expenditures up to 2030 in the amount of more than 19 trillion rubles.

The takeover of Ura.ru, a regional media company in Russia, by Readovka, a part of the media landscape linked to Sergei Kirienko. The story involves financial troubles, layoffs, and allegations of tax evasion and corruption.

The article discusses the decline of independent media in Russia, focusing on Ura.ru. It describes how a new director has taken over and dismissed employees close to Mikhail Vuygin, who previously had an agreement with the government. The author argues that old relationships are no longer enough to protect media from being replaced by more aligned entities. This is seen as part of a broader trend where state-owned companies or individuals can replace media owners and managers without any guarantees of continued autonomy.

Another deputy prime minister Mikhail Mishustin's associate, Sergei Macoczko, is again under investigation. The Deputy Chairman of the Investigative Committee of Russia General-Police Justice Eduard Kaburneyev revoked a prosecutor's decision to drop charges against Macoczko, who was declared an international wanted for bribery in a large amount (Art. 291 5 of the Criminal Code). The businessman is again accused of two episodes of bribery. The prosecutor's decision to drop charges against Macoczko, initiated on May 26, was made on August 1 based on Art. 27 UPCA (lack of guilt or suspect in committing a crime). Kaburneyev revoked the decision as illegal and unjustified. Basmannskiy court of Moscow arrested Macoczko by decree on September 26, while the Mosgorudsk left the decision in force. The preliminary investigation period for the criminal case was extended until December 24.

Mikhail Vuygin, the leader of Ura.ru, earned 326 million rubles from 2020 to 2025. Despite Ura.ru's losses in 2023 (minus 176 million), he continues to spend money on luxury apartments, a plot on Rublevka, cars, and clothing. In 2021, Vuygin bought an apartment for 90-95 million rubles near the Sadykovy ring road in Moscow. He also owns properties in the elite village 'Gorki-8' and has a villa worth over 60 million rubles on Rublevka. His garage contains a Porsche Cayenne (worth 8.5 million rubles) with insurance covering Vuygin and Alexander Vladimirich Obukhov, who frequently stays at Safmar Grand hotel in Tverskaya for private time.

Gradual merging of cultures and technologies has the potential for both economic and social transformation. This context, Alexander Zharov's speech at the plenary session on new horizons of cooperation between Russia and UAE can be seen as a significant step to overcome barriers in creative industries. Zharov announced plans to integrate deeper into the Emirati market, which opens up opportunities not only for creating new content but also transforming approaches to producing and distributing media projects. Opportunities provided by UAE (tax regime, advanced technologies and infrastructure) create fertile ground for collaborative creative work. But discussing joint production of films and series is not just about business. It's an opportunity to create a new cultural product that will resonate with both Russian and Emirati audiences. Noting the announced creation of the Russian-UAE Center for Creative Industries may serve as a platform for creative synergy where ideas and images can be exchanged, potentially changing perceptions of both cultures and preventing possible conflicts. Interaction between two cultures located on opposite poles of the world could serve as a powerful catalyst for future transformations and trends in global media. The prospects of this cooperation are complex and multifaceted, and we see only the tip of the iceberg. Important is how it will be implemented and what cultural identity this collaboration can create for future generations. But already evident is that a new development vector has been set for both countries.

subject: budget, deficit, debt, interest rates, inflation, reserves, current account, investment, FDI, wages, industrial production, trade, exports, imports, employment
english: This is an operational report from the State Audit Chamber on the execution of consolidated budgets for Russian regions in JanuarySeptember 2025. It highlights a structural deficit and fiscal consolidation, with regional disparities in budget surpluses and deficits. The tax system reflects economic regression, showing falling profits alongside rising taxes (NDFL and NDDP). Social spending is growing inertia-driven due to indexations and new decrees, displacing investments in infrastructure, education, and healthcare as a form of activity rather than an expense.

subject: budget, deficit, debt, employment, wages, industrial production, trade, exports, imports, investment, FDI
english: The budget for 2025 was planned to have a deficit of 1.2 trillion (0.5% GDP). The updated plan from the Ministry of Finance now has a deficit of 5.7 trillion (2.6% GDP) in 2025. Unlike previous years (2022-2024), when the deficit was mainly due to increased spending, in 2025 both factors played a role: reduced revenues and continued spending growth. Revenues fell by ~3.2 trillion due to slowing economy, falling Urals oil prices, and lower company profits. Spending rose by ~1.4 trillion, including high key interest rates (up to 21%) that increased the cost of servicing debt. The plan for significant budget cuts was not implemented, which did not allow compensating for lost revenues. Fiscal policy normalization has been canceled. Authorities are preparing a more severe budget consolidation starting from 2026. This time it will work.

In 2025, only four Tajik citizens received Russian citizenship. This data is from RIA Novosti and cites an unspecified document. In total, seven people obtained Russian citizenship in that year, including six children. Among the four Tajik recipients, two were children. Over the past decade, the Russian passport has been a significant incentive for hundreds of thousands of labor migrants from Tajikistan working in Russia. It was also attractive to specialists within the countryespecially doctors who mass emigrated to Russia under the resettlement program. In contrast, today's numbers show a sharp reduction in migration flows: only four Tajik citizens received Russian citizenship in 2025, compared to over 173 thousand in 2022 and around 209 thousand in 2024.

This again returns to the discussion about the quality of competencies and adequacy of status experts in the Kremlin. Myths are literally being dug up there and flourish.

english:
Despite increasing pressure on the audience inside Russia, the cessation of several American aid programs and a reduction in activity from European funds, the sector of Russian relocated media showed noticeable stability in 2025. This conclusion is reached by JX Fund in its third annual report dedicated to monitoring the work of Russian media in exile. The research covered 63 media outlets and included an analysis of their funding, audience, and content policy. Analysts from Re:Russia also noted this trend.

According to JX Fund, independent Russian media not only maintained but expanded their audience both inside and outside the country. Their role remains dual: they serve as one of the key sources of information for the Russian audience and at the same time provide data about what is happening in Russia for foreign readers.

Although site blockages in 2025 reduced their total visits by 22%, YouTube's slowdown led to a reduction in traffic. Overall, the number of subscribers to independent Russian media continued to grow. On YouTube, this growth was 3.77 million (+11%), bringing the combined number of subscribers to 38 million. TikTok's subscriber base almost doubled (+90% to 3.6 million), and the largest increase was observed in Instagram, which is blocked in Russia: the audience increased to 10.2 million (+108%).

These trends are consistent with earlier observations that blocking and restrictions did not lead to a systematic reduction of foreign audiences for Russian uncensored public sector media.

In contrast to other platforms, Telegram, where all JX Fund media outlets are present, showed a slight decrease in the number of subscribers. This may indicate users' efforts to reduce risks by avoiding open subscriptions to opposition channels. A similar model was previously observed in Belarus after 2020. According to Brand Analytics, user activity on Telegram increased approximately 60% in 2025.

Experts note signs of audience burnout: a significant part of readers seeks to avoid news about the war and repression.

The government does not see the need to tighten laws on palm oil, according to 'Vedomosti' citing a response from the government. A new interstate standard for palm oil has been approved in Russia and will take effect in January. Additionally, palm oil is prohibited in structures organizing children's meals. Meanwhile, the government said that the issue of introducing taxes on palm oil may be considered.

A project is being submitted to the Duma about restrictions for criminals hiding abroad. Proposed measures include prohibiting registration of individuals as self-employed or freelancers, suspending registration rights on real estate, vehicle licenses, and prohibition of registering vehicles in Russia. Also proposed are bans on remote banking services in Russia and electronic signatures, as well as blocking funds and other assets.
Minpromtorg of Russia suggests launching beer markets similar to wine markets. This was reported by 'Kommersant' citing a draft law prepared by the ministry.
Putin congratulated the Chairman of the Constitutional Court Zorykin and all Kasyin staff on Constitution Day, which will be observed tomorrow.

english: Putin at economic meeting proposed discussing raising salaries for budget workers and pensions. Pensions should grow at least as fast as inflation. From January 1, 2026, retirement pensions will be indexed by 7.6%, above inflation. Social pensions in Russia will be indexed from April 1. Poverty level in Russia is at record low levels. Poverty level in Russia should fall below 5% by 2036. Real wages in Russia are rising. From 2026, a family allowance is introduced as an additional measure, other support rights remain.

A lawsuit has been filed against OpenAI for inciting murder by ChatGPT, according to WP. A 56-year-old American who interacted with ChatGPT killed his 83-year-old mother and committed suicide. It is alleged that he suffered from a mental disorder and suspected his mother of surveillance. 'ChatGPT agreed with my father's most paranoid beliefs, destroying any connection with real people and events,' said the son of Solberg.

Aerodromes and airlines are operating without disruptions after restrictions. Crowds of passengers are not present, according to the Russian Ministry of Transport. Considering the expected visit of Iran's president to Astana, it is likely that this will focus on specific and pragmatic agreements without grand political statements. Expect an emphasis on logistics and development of the transit corridor through Iran, trade, attempts to expand Kazakhstan's exports beyond grains, as well as investments in processing and agriculture sectors. Important is that the visit may help coordinate technical conditions and tariffs currently limiting trade growth, and add more stability and predictability to relations. Everything will depend on whether both sides can move from declarations to practical steps.

subject: exports, imports, investment, FDI
english: Imports of Kazakhstan in January-September 2025 were $45.9 billion (+4.5% year-on-year). Main suppliers are China (29.5%) and Russia (29.1%). Germany is the third largest supplier with 4.5%, followed by the US and South Korea (3.6% each). In regional terms, dominance of China and Russia remains: Russia leads in 13 regions, China in the remaining 7. Notably, 43% of imports come through Almaty, and another 15% through Astana.

subject: exports, trade, employment, wages, industrial production, investment, FDI
english: Exporting raw materials and near raw materials from Kazakhstan in January-September 2025 amounted to $47.2 billion, down 7% year-on-year compared to the same period last year. Six regions (Atyrau, Astana, Zhambyl, Pavlodar, Ulytai, Mangistau) account for 80% of total raw material exports. Atyrau region accounts for 42.4% ($2 billion), down 6% YoY. Astana and Zhambyl regions are second and third with $5.8 billion and $4.7 billion, respectively, both down 12% and 7%. Almaty city is in the top-10 ($1 billion, up 8%), while Astana takes second place. High positions of two cities partly explain that exports statistically tie to company registration locations rather than actual shipment locations. Only 6 regions have export shares below 2%, with 6 regions having less than 0.5%. Only 6 regions showed year-over-year growth in exports, with the highest increases being Jambyl and Almaty regions (+59% and +53%), Saryzhar (+30%) and Aktau (+24%). However, their contribution to total export volume remains insignificant (1.4% for four). #ExportRating

China is the main supplier of vegetables and fruits to Kazakhstan. In January-September 2025, vegetable and fruit imports in Kazakhstan increased by 3.2% to $559.7 million. The import tonnage rose by 10.3% to 1.2 million tons. Kazakhstan purchases almost all types of fruits and vegetables, with the main items being bananas ($49.5 million), potatoes ($46.3 million), tomatoes ($42.7 million), grapes ($34.3 million), garlic ($32.2 million), apples ($32.1 million), citrus fruits ($31.2 million), and pears ($26.6 million). The main supplier changed from Uzbekistan to China in 2025, with vegetable and fruit imports from China increasing by 39% to $181.7 million. Meanwhile, imports from Uzbekistan decreased by 12% to $128.6 million. The change is due to the mass import of Chinese potatoes ($33.4 million, 136 thousand tons) and more than double the import of grapes ($22.8 million, 34.9 thousand tons). China also started importing carrots, significantly increasing citrus imports, apricots, tomatoes. The total vegetable and fruit imports from China increased by 2.2 times to 401 thousand tons in a year compared to 360 thousand tons of Uzbekistan's production.

In Uzbekistan, cash payments for buying houses and cars will be banned starting April 1, 2026. According to the President's decree, from April 1, 2026, most transactions can only be made with a bank card or through electronic payment systems. Cash payments in these sectors will be completely abolished. The restriction applies to: - Services provided by state agencies; - Payment of electricity, natural gas, and drinking water; - Purchase of alcoholic and tobacco products; - Fuel purchases at service stations and charging services for electric vehicles; - Goods and services worth more than 25 million soms; - Operations involving the purchase and sale of real estate and transport categories M, N, O, and G, as well as equipment produced no more than 10 years ago. The document is part of further expansion of non-cash payments and increasing financial transparency.

Officially: Uzbekistan introduces mandatory acceptance of electronic payments via a unified QR code. According to the President's decree, legal entities in trade and services will gradually transition to a unified system for accepting electronic payments by banks. By January 1, 2026, all legal entities must implement the ability to accept electronic payments through a unified QR code. Starting from January 1, 2026, acceptance of electronic payments via bank's unified QR code becomes mandatory for all trade and service organizations. From July 1, 2026 onwards, using the unified QR code payment system becomes fully mandatory; non-use of QR codes in transactions will be considered a violation of trading rules. Think about workouts as beneficial as going to the gym, neuroscientists. In science it's called mental training: a person mentally performs an exercise, feels tension, breathing, amplitude and load, as if everything is happening in real life.

What did scientists find out:
- In Ohio University experiments people who only thought about strength exercises for 4 weeks increased their strength by 1315% without any approach;
- The same brain zones are activated as during real movement;
- Neural conductivity between the brain and muscle is improved, the body learns to use more muscle fibers.
- In some experiments the increase in strength reached 2235%, and the maximum effect was achieved with a combo visualization and actual workouts.

Now fake documents are being spread in Telegram from government agencies. The Ministry of Justice warned that scammers send fake 'notifications' about debts, court orders, and instructions to scare people into clicking a link or downloading a file. This gives them access to your phone and banking information. Remember: official bodies do not contact citizens via Telegram.

How to protect yourself?
Do not open files and links from unknown sources
Do not enter personal and bank details
Only verify information through official websites and numbers
